(1994–2011) }} }} The '''Korean conflict''' is based on the division between the [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] in the north and the [[Republic of Korea]] in the south, both of which claim to be the government of [[Korea|the entire peninsula]]. During the [[Cold War]], North Korea was backed by the [[Soviet Union]], [[China]] and other [[communist states]], and South Korea was backed by the [[United States]] and [[Western Bloc|its capitalist allies]]. The [[division of Korea]] by external powers occurred at the end of [[World War II]] in 1945, and tensions erupted into the [[Korean War]], which lasted from 1950 to 1953. When the war ended, the country was devastated, but the division remained. North and South Korea continued a military standoff, with periodic clashes. The conflict survived the collapse of the [[Eastern Bloc]] of 1989 to 1991. The U.S. maintains a [[United States Forces Korea|military presence in the South]] to assist South Korea in accordance with the [[Mutual Defense Treaty Between the United States and the Republic of Korea|ROK–US Mutual Defense Treaty]]. In 1997, U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] described the division of Korea as the "Cold War's last divide".{{cite book |author= Hyung Gu Lynn |date= 2007 |title= Bipolar Orders: The Two Koreas since 1989 |publisher= Zed Books |p=3}} In 2002, U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] described North Korea as a member of an "[[axis of evil]]".{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |p=504}}{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |p=112}} Facing increasing isolation, North Korea developed missile and nuclear capabilities. In 2018, North and South Korea, and the United States, held a series of summits which promised peace and nuclear disarmament. This led to the Panmunjom Declaration on April 27 2018, where the two nations agreed to work together to end the conflict. ==Background== {{see also|Korean Empire|Korea under Japanese rule}} Korea was [[Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty|annexed]] by the [[Empire of Japan]] in 1910. In the following decades during the [[Japanese occupation of Korea]], nationalist and radical groups emerged, mostly in exile, to struggle for [[Korean independence movement|independence]]. Divergent in their outlooks and approaches, these groups failed to unite in one national movement.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=31–37}}{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=156–60}} Based in China, the [[Korean Provisional Government]] failed to obtain widespread recognition.{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=159–60}} The many leaders agitating for Korean independence included the conservative and U.S.-educated [[Syngman Rhee]], who lobbied the U.S. government, and the Communist [[Kim Il-sung]], who fought a guerrilla war against the Japanese from neighboring [[Manchuria]] to the north of Korea.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=35–36, 46–47}} Following the [[Surrender of Japan|end of the occupation]], many high-ranking Koreans were accused of collaborating with [[Japanese imperialism]].{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=48–49}} An intense and bloody struggle between various figures and political groups aspiring to lead Korea ensued.{{cite book| title = Korea's Twentieth-Century Odyssey | last = Robinson | first = Michael E | year = 2007 | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | location = Honolulu | isbn = 978-0-8248-3174-5 |p=103}} ==Division of Korea== {{Campaignbox Korean Cold War}} {{main|Division of Korea}} {{see also|United States Army Military Government in Korea}} [[Image:KMAG Headquarters, Seoul, South Korea circa 1950.jpg|thumb|213px|left| US Military Advisory Group Headquarters, South Korea, c. 1950]] On August 9, 1945, in the closing days of [[World War II]], the [[Soviet Union]] [[Soviet–Japanese War|declared war on Japan]] and advanced into [[Korea]], at the request of the United States. Though the Soviet declaration of war had been agreed by the Allies at the [[Yalta Conference]], the US government had agreed with the Russian government earlier that the Soviet advance would stop at the 38th parallel, which it did. The US government forces arrived a few weeks later and occupied the area south of the 38th parallel, including the capital, [[Seoul]]. This was incorporated into [[General Order No. 1]] to Japanese forces after the [[surrender of Japan]] on August 15. On August 24, the Red Army entered [[Pyongyang]] and established a military government over Korea north of the parallel. American forces landed in the south on September 8 and established the [[United States Army Military Government in Korea]].{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=50}} The American government had not consulted or asked permission of the Korean people or their representatives to conduct this division of the country. The division of the Korean peninsula by the US and Russia would set the stage for the civil war in 1950. The Allies had originally envisaged a joint trusteeship which would steer Korea towards independence, but most Korean nationalists wanted independence immediately.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=59}} Meanwhile, the wartime co-operation between the Soviet Union and the US deteriorated as the [[Cold War]] took hold. Both occupying powers began promoting into positions of authority Koreans aligned with their side of politics and marginalizing their opponents. Many of these emerging political leaders were returning exiles with little popular support.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=50–51, 59}}{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=194–95}} In North Korea, the Soviet Union supported Korean Communists. Kim Il-sung, who from 1941 had served in the Soviet Army, became the major political figure.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=56}} Society was centralized and collectivized, following the Soviet model.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=68}} Politics in the South were more tumultuous, but the strongly anti-Communist Syngman Rhee, who had been educated in the United States, was positioned as the most prominent politician.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=66, 69}} The rival leaders, [[Kim Koo]] and [[Lyuh Woon-hyung]], were assassinated. Other popular leaders were deemed "leftists" by the US occupying forces and fled to the north to escape imprisonment. As a result, two antagonistic states emerged, with diametrically opposed political, economic, and social systems. In [[South Korea]], a [[South Korean Constitutional Assembly election, 1948|general election]] was held on May 10, 1948. The Republic of Korea (or ROK) was established with [[Syngman Rhee]] as President, and formally replaced the US military occupation on August 15. In North Korea, the [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] (or DPRK) was declared on September 9, with [[Kim Il-sung]], as prime minister. Soviet occupation forces left the DPRK on December 10, 1948. US forces left the ROK the following year, though the US [[Korean Military Advisory Group]] remained to train the [[Republic of Korea Army]].{{cite book| title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=255–56}} The new regimes even adopted different [[Names of Korea|names for Korea]]: the North choosing ''Choson'', and the South ''Hanguk''.{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |p=178}} Both opposing governments considered themselves to be the government of the whole of Korea (as they do to this day), and both saw the division as temporary.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=72}}{{cite book| title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=505–06}} Kim Il-sung lobbied [[Stalin]] and [[Mao Zedong|Mao]] for support in a war of reunification. [[Syngman Rhee]] repeatedly expressed his desire to conquer the North.{{cite book| title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=249–58}}{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=71}} In 1948 North Korea, which had almost all of the generators, turned off the electricity supply to the South.{{cite book| title = Korea's Twentieth-Century Odyssey | last = Robinson | first = Michael E | year = 2007 | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | location = Honolulu | isbn = 978-0-8248-3174-5 |p=120}} In the lead-up to the outbreak of civil war, there were frequent clashes along the 38th parallel, especially at [[Kaesong]] and [[Ongjin County, South Hwanghae|Ongjin]], initiated by both sides.{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=247–53}}{{citation |last=Stueck |first=William W. |year=2002 |title=Rethinking the Korean War: A New Diplomatic and Strategic History |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=Princeton, NJ |isbn=0-691-11847-7|p=71}} Throughout this period there were uprisings in the South, such as the [[Jeju Uprising]] and the [[Yeosu–Suncheon Rebellion]], that were brutally suppressed. In all, over one hundred thousand lives were lost in fighting across Korea before the Korean War began.{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | authorlink= Sheila Miyoshi Jager| title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|p=4}} ==Korean War== {{main|Korean War}} [[File:Korean War Memorial, Pyongyang, North Korea.jpg|thumb|right|The [[North Korea Peace Museum|Korean War Memorial]] in Pyongyang, North Korea, with the pyramidal [[Ryugyong Hotel]] in the background]] [[File:Korean War bombing Wonsan.jpg|thumb|left|US planes bombing [[Wonsan]], North Korea, 1951]] By 1950, North Korea had clear military superiority over the South. The Soviet occupiers had armed it with surplus weaponry and provided training. Many troops returning to North Korea were battle-hardened from their participation in the [[Chinese Civil War]], which had just ended.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=73}}{{cite book| title = Korea's Twentieth-Century Odyssey | last = Robinson | first = Michael E | year = 2007 | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | location = Honolulu | isbn = 978-0-8248-3174-5 |pp=114–15}} Kim Il-sung expected a quick victory, predicting that there would be pro-Communist uprisings in the South and that the US would not intervene.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=72, 77–78}} Rather than perceiving the conflict as a civil war, however, the West saw it in Cold War terms as Communist aggression, related to recent events in China and Eastern Europe.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=86}} North Korea invaded the South on June 25, 1950, and swiftly overran most of the country. In September 1950 [[United Nations Command|United Nations force]], led by the United States, intervened to defend the South, and following the [[Battle of Incheon|Incheon Landing]] and [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter|breakout from the Busan Perimeter]], [[UN Offensive, 1950|rapidly advanced into North Korea]]. As they neared the border with China, Chinese forces intervened on behalf of North Korea, shifting the balance of the war again. Fighting ended on July 27, 1953, with an [[Korean Armistice Agreement|armistice]] that approximately restored the original boundaries between North and South Korea. Korea was devastated. Around three million civilians and soldiers had been killed. Seoul was in ruins, having changed hands four times.{{cite book| title = Korea's Twentieth-Century Odyssey | last = Robinson | first = Michael E | year = 2007 | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | location = Honolulu | isbn = 978-0-8248-3174-5 |p=119}} Almost every substantial building in North Korea had been destroyed.{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=297–98}}{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|pp=237–42}} As a result, North Koreans developed a deep-seated antagonism towards the US. ==Armistice== {{main|Korean Armistice Agreement}} Negotiations for an armistice began on July 10, 1951, as the war continued. The main issues were the establishment of a new demarcation line and the exchange of prisoners. After Stalin died, the Soviet Union brokered concessions which led to an agreement on July 27, 1953.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=81–82}} Syngman Rhee opposed the armistice because it left Korea divided. As negotiations drew to a close, he attempted to sabotage the arrangements for the release of prisoners, and led mass rallies against the armistice.{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|pp=278–81}} He refused to sign the agreement, but reluctantly agreed to abide by it.{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |p=20}} The armistice inaugurated an official ceasefire but did not lead to a peace treaty.{{cite book |author= Hyung Gu Lynn |date= 2007 |title= Bipolar Orders: The Two Koreas since 1989 |publisher= Zed Books |p=8}} It established the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]] (DMZ), a buffer zone between the two sides, that intersected the 38th parallel but did not follow it. Despite its name, the border was, and continues to be, one of the most militarized in the world. North Korea announced that it will no longer abide by the armistice at least six times, in the years 1994, 1996, 2003, 2006, 2009, and 2013.{{cite web |url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2009/05/28/46/0401000000AEN20090528004200315F.HTML |title=Chronology of major North Korean statements on the Korean War armistice |publisher=Yonhap |work=News |date=2009-05-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6F0QuE8HO?url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2009/05/28/46/0401000000AEN20090528004200315F.HTML |archivedate=2013-03-10 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21709917 |title=North Korea ends peace pacts with South |publisher=BBC News |date=2013-03-08 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6F0Qo2CpN?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21709917 |archivedate=2013-03-10 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==The Cold War continues== [[File:USS Pueblo, Pyongyang, 2012.jpg|thumb|right|The captured USS ''Pueblo'' being visited by tourists in Pyongyang]] After the war, the Chinese forces left, but [[United States Forces Korea|US forces remained in the South]]. Sporadic conflict continued between North and South Korea. On October 1, 1953, the United States and South Korea signed a [[Mutual Defense Treaty Between the United States and the Republic of Korea|defense treaty]].{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=206}} In 1958, the United States stationed nuclear weapons in South Korea.{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |p=493}} In 1961, North Korea signed mutual defense treaties with the USSR and China.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=208}} During this period, North Korea was described by former CIA director [[Robert Gates]] to be the "toughest intelligence target in the world".{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | page = 48 | isbn = 9780465031238}} Alongside the military confrontation, there has been a propaganda war, including [[Balloon propaganda campaigns in Korea|balloon propaganda campaigns]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43806930|title=North and South Korea: The petty side of diplomacy|first=Yvette|last=Tan|publisher=BBC|date=25 April 2018}} The opposing regimes aligned themselves with opposing sides in the [[Cold War]]. Both sides received recognition as the legitimate government of Korea from the opposing blocs.{{cite report | title = The DPRK Diplomatic Relations | last1 = Wertz | first1 = Daniel | last2 = Oh | first2 = JJ | last3 = Kim | first3 = Insung | year = 2015 | publisher = National Committee on North Korea | url = http://www.ncnk.org/resources/publications/NCNK_Issue_Brief_DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations.pdf | p = 1 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161228074114/http://www.ncnk.org/resources/publications/NCNK_Issue_Brief_DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations.pdf | archivedate = 2016-12-28 | df = }}{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | page = 123 | isbn = 9780465031238}} North Korea presented itself as a champion of orthodox Communism, distinct from the Soviet Union and China. The regime developed the doctrine of [[Juche]] or self-reliance, which included extreme military mobilization.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=93, 95–97}} In response to the threat of nuclear war, it constructed extensive facilities underground and in the mountains.{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |p=497}} The [[Pyongyang Metro]] opened in the 1970s, with the capacity to double as bomb shelter.{{cite book|last=Springer|first=Chris|title=Pyongyang: the hidden history of the North Korean capital|year=2003|publisher=Entente Bt|isbn=978-963-00-8104-7|page=125}} Until the early 1970s, North Korea was economically the equal of the South.{{cite book| title = Korea's Twentieth-Century Odyssey | last = Robinson | first = Michael E | year = 2007 | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | location = Honolulu | isbn = 978-0-8248-3174-5 |p=148}} South Korea became a strongly anti-Communist military dictatorship and [[South Korea in the Vietnam War|was heavily involved in the Vietnam War]].{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=107, 116}} North Korea's occupation left behind a guerrilla movement that persisted in the Cholla provinces. Tensions between North and South escalated in the late 1960s with a series of low-level armed clashes known as the [[Korean DMZ Conflict (1966-1969)|Korean DMZ Conflict]]. In 1966, Kim declared "liberation of the south" to be a "national duty".{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|p=366}} In 1968, North Korean commandos launched the [[Blue House Raid]], an unsuccessful attempt to assassinate the South Korean President [[Park Chung-hee]]. Shortly after, the US spy ship [[USS Pueblo (AGER-2)|Pueblo]] was captured by the North Korean navy.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=99}} The Americans saw the crisis in terms of the global confrontation with Communism, but, rather than orchestrating the incident, the Soviet government was concerned by it.{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|p=371}} The crisis was initiated by Kim, inspired by Communist successes in the Vietnam War.{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 50–51 | isbn = 9780465031238}} In 1967, Korean-born composer [[Isang Yun]] was kidnapped in West Germany by South Korean agents and imprisoned in South Korea for spying for the North. He was released after an international outcry.{{cite book|last1=Fraker|first1=Sara E.|title=The Oboe Works of Isang Yun|date=2009|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=9781109217803|page=27}} In 1969, North Korea [[1969 EC-121 shootdown incident|shot down a US EC-121 spy plane]] over the Sea of Japan, killing all 31 crew on board, which constitutes the largest single loss of US aircrew during the Cold War.{{cite book | last =Larson | first =George A. | coauthors = | year = 2001| url = | title = Cold war shoot downs: Part two| work = Air Classics | publisher = Challenge Publications Inc.}} In 1969, [[Korean Air Lines YS-11 hijacking|Korean Air Lines YS-11 was hijacked]] and flown to North Korea. Similarly, in 1970, the hijackers of [[Japan Airlines Flight 351]] were given asylum in North Korea.{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |p=47}} In response to the Blue House Raid, the South Korean government set up [[209th Detachment, 2325th Group|a special unit]] to assassinate Kim Il-sung, but the mission was aborted in 1972.{{cite book |author= Hyung Gu Lynn |date= 2007 |title= Bipolar Orders: The Two Koreas since 1989 |publisher= Zed Books |p=158}} In 1974 a [[Mun Se-gwang|North Korean sympathizer]] attempted to assassinate President Park and killed his wife, [[Yuk Young-soo]].{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 42–45 | isbn = 9780465031238}} In 1976, the [[Panmunjeom Axe incident]] led to the death of two US Army officers in the DMZ and threatened to trigger a wider war.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=210}}{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 59–66 | isbn = 9780465031238}} In the 1970s, North Korea [[North Korean abductions of Japanese citizens|kidnapped a number of Japanese citizens]]. In 1976, in now-declassified minutes, US Deputy Secretary of Defense [[William Clements]] told [[Henry Kissinger]] that there had been 200 raids or incursions into North Korea from the South, though not by the U.S. military.{{cite web |url=https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1969-76ve12/d286 |title=Minutes of Washington Special Actions Group Meeting, Washington, August 25, 1976, 10:30 a.m. |date=25 August 1976 |accessdate=12 May 2012 |publisher=[[Office of the Historian]], U.S. Department of State |quote=Clements: I like it. It doesn't have an overt character. I have been told that there have been 200 other such operations and that none of these have surfaced. Kissinger: It is different for us with the War Powers Act. I don't remember any such operations. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120925121535/http://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1969-76ve12/d286 |archivedate=25 September 2012 |df= }} According to South Korean politicians who have campaigned for compensation for the survivors, more than 7,700 secret agents infiltrated North Korea from 1953 to 1972, of which about 5,300 are believed not to have returned.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/15/world/south-korean-movie-unlocks-door-on-a-once-secret-past.html|title=South Korean Movie Unlocks Door on a Once-Secret Past|first=Norimitsu|last=Onishi|publisher=New York Times|date=15 February 2004}} Details of only a few of these incursions have become public, including raids by South Korean forces in 1967 that had sabotaged about 50 North Korean facilities.{{cite news |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/02/116_80936.html |title=S. Korea raided North with captured agents in 1967 |publisher=The Korea Times |author=Lee Tae-hoon |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=12 May 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001195904/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/02/116_80936.html |archivedate=1 October 2012 |df= }} Other missions included targeting advisers from China and the Soviet Union in order to undermine relations between North Korea and its allies.{{cite web|url=https://news.joins.com/article/12709883|title=[현장 속으로] 돌아오지 못한 북파공작원 7726명|date=28 September 2013|publisher=}} During the 1970s, both North and South began building up their military capacity.{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 47–49, 54–55 | isbn = 9780465031238}} It was discovered that North Korea had dug tunnels under the DMZ which could accommodate thousands of troops.{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 45–47 | isbn = 9780465031238}} Alarmed at the prospect of US disengagement, South Korea began a [[South Korean nuclear research programs|secret nuclear weapons program]] which was strongly opposed by Washington.{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 55–59 | isbn = 9780465031238}} In 1977, US President [[Jimmy Carter]] proposed the withdrawal of troops from South Korea. There was a widespread backlash in America and in South Korea, and critics argued that this would allow the North to capture Seoul. Carter postponed the move, and his successor [[Ronald Reagan]] reversed the policy, increasing troop numbers to forty-three thousand.{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|pp=396–413}} After Reagan supplied the South with [[F-16]] fighters, and after Kim Il-sung visited Moscow in 1984, the USSR recommenced military aid and co-operation with the North.{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 122–23 | isbn = 9780465031238}} Unrest in the South came to a head with the [[Gwangju Uprising]] in 1980. The dictatorship equated dissent with North Korean subversion. On the other hand, some young protesters viewed the US as complicit in political repression and identified with the North's nationalist propaganda.{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|pp=417–24}}{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 98–103 | isbn = 9780465031238}} In 1983 North Korea carried out the [[Rangoon bombing]], a failed assassination attempt against South Korean President [[Chun Doo-hwan]] while he was visiting Burma.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=147–48}} The bombing of [[Korean Air Flight 858]] in 1987, in the lead up to the [[Seoul Olympics]], led to the US government placing North Korea on its list of terrorist countries.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=165}}{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |pp=46–47}} In the 1980s, the South Korean government built a 98m tall flagpole in its village of [[Daeseong-dong]] in the DMZ. In response, North Korea built a 160m tall flagpole in its nearby village of [[Kijŏng-dong]]. ==Isolation and Confrontation== [[File:US Navy 090320-N-9928E-304 The aircraft carrier USS John C. Stennis (CVN 74) and ships of the John C. Stennis Carrier Strike Group are underway in formation with naval vessels from the Republic of Korea.jpg|thumb|right|Vessels of US Carrier Strike Group Three sail in formation with ROK Navy ships during Key Resolve/Foal Eagle 2009]] [[File:2010.11.23 북한 해안포 발사로 불타는 연평도 (7445571570).jpg|thumb|left|Yeonpyeong Island under North Korean attack]] As the Cold War ended, North Korea lost the support of the Soviet Union and plunged into an [[North Korean famine|economic crisis]]. With the death of Leader [[Kim Il-sung]] in 1994,{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |pp=173–76}} there were expectations that the North Korean government could collapse and the peninsula would be reunified.{{cite book| title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |p=509}}{{cite book |author= Hyung Gu Lynn |date= 2007 |title= Bipolar Orders: The Two Koreas since 1989 |publisher= Zed Books |p=93}} In response to its increased isolation, North Korea redoubled its efforts to [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|develop nuclear weapons and intercontinental ballistic missiles]]. In 1994, US President [[Bill Clinton]] considered bombing the [[Yongbyon Nuclear Scientific Research Center|Yongbyon nuclear reactor]], but he later dismissed this option when he was advised that if war broke out, it could cost 52,000 US and 490,000 South Korean military casualties in the first three months, as well as a large number of civilian casualties.{{cite book | last = Jager | first = Sheila Miyoshi | title = Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea | year = 2013 | publisher = Profile Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84668-067-0|p=439}}{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | page = 247 | isbn = 9780465031238}} Instead, in 1994, the US and North Korea signed an [[Agreed Framework]] which aimed to freeze North Korea's nuclear program. In 1998, South Korean President [[Kim Dae-jung]] initiated the [[Sunshine Policy]] which aimed to foster better relations with the North.{{cite book| title = The Making of Modern Korea | last = Buzo | first = Adrian | year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| location = London | isbn = 0-415-23749-1 |p=178}} However, in the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]], U.S. President [[George W Bush]] denounced the policy, and in 2002 branded North Korea as a member of an "[[Axis of Evil]]". [[Six-party talks]] involving North and South Korea, the United States, Russia, Japan, and China commenced in 2003 but failed to achieve a resolution. In 2006, North Korea announced it had successfully conducted its [[2006 North Korean nuclear test|first nuclear test]].{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |p=1}} The Sunshine Policy was formally abandoned by South Korean President [[Lee Myung-bak]] after his election in 2007.[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/South-Korea-Formally-Declares-End-to-Sunshine-Policy--108904544.html South Korea Formally Declares End to Sunshine Policy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412215246/http://www.voanews.com/english/news/South-Korea-Formally-Declares-End-to-Sunshine-Policy--108904544.html |date=2012-04-12 }}, [http://www.voanews.com Voice of America] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514131027/http://www.voanews.com/ |date=2012-05-14 }}, 18 November 2010 At the start of the twenty first century, it was estimated that the concentration of firepower in the area between Pyongyang and Seoul was greater than that in central Europe during the Cold War.{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |p=vi}} The North's [[Korean People's Army]] was numerically twice the size of South Korea's military and had the capacity to devastate Seoul with artillery and missile bombardment. South Korea's military, however, was assessed as being technically superior in many ways.{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |pp=138–43}}{{cite book |author= Hyung Gu Lynn |date= 2007 |title= Bipolar Orders: The Two Koreas since 1989 |publisher= Zed Books |pp=142–43}} [[United States Forces Korea|US forces remained in South Korea]] and carried out annual military exercises with South Korean forces, including [[Key Resolve]], [[Foal Eagle]], and [[Ulchi-Freedom Guardian]]. These have been routinely denounced by North Korea as acts of aggression.{{cite news|title=Backgrounder: How DPRK has condemned U.S.-S. Korea joint military exercises|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-08/22/c_135623963.htm|publisher=''Xinhua''|date=22 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823164622/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-08/22/c_135623963.htm|archivedate=23 August 2016|df=}}{{cite book | title = Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History| last = Cumings| first = Bruce| authorlink = Bruce Cumings| year = 2005| publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]]| location = New York| isbn = 0-393-32702-7 |pp=488–89, 494–96}}{{Cite book| last1= Oberdorfer| first1=Don| last2=Carlin| first2=Robert | title=The Two Koreas: A Contemporary History | publisher = Basic Books| year = 2014 | pages = 61, 213 | isbn = 9780465031238}} Between 1997 and 2016, the North Korea government accused other governments of declaring war against it 200 times.{{cite news|title=China, North Korea criticize new U.S. sanctions|url=https://www.nknews.org/2016/07/china-north-korea-criticize-new-u-s-sanctions/|first=Leo|last=Byrne|publisher=''NK News''|date=8 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708130743/https://www.nknews.org/2016/07/china-north-korea-criticize-new-u-s-sanctions/|archivedate=8 July 2016|df=}} Analysts have described the US garrison as a tripwire ensuring American military involvement, but some have queried whether sufficient reinforcements would be forthcoming.{{cite book | title = Korea| last = Bluth | first = Christoph | year = 2008| publisher = Polity Press| location = Cambridge| isbn = 978-07456-3357-2 |pp=144–45}} During this period, two North Korean submarines were captured after being stranded on the South Korean coast, [[1996 Gangneung submarine infiltration incident|one near Gangneung in 1996]] and [[1998 Sokcho submarine incident|one near Sokcho in 1998]]. In December 1998, the South Korean navy sank a North Korean [[semi-submersible]] in the [[Battle of Yeosu]]. In 2001, the Japanese Coast Guard sank a North Korean spy ship in the [[Battle of Amami-Ōshima]]. South Korea ceased sending "North Korea Demolition Agents" to raid the North in the early 2000s.{{cite web|url=https://news.joins.com/article/12709883|title=[현장 속으로] 돌아오지 못한 북파공작원 7726명|date=28 September 2013|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/02/116_80936.html|title=S. Korea raided North with captured agents in 1967|date=7 February 2011|publisher=}} Conflict intensified near the disputed maritime boundary known as the [[Northern Limit Line]] in the [[Yellow Sea]]. In 1999 and 2002, there were clashes between the navies of North and South Korea, known as the [[First Battle of Yeonpyeong|First]] and [[Second battle of Yeonpyeong]]. On March 26, 2010, a South Korean naval vessel, the [[ROKS Cheonan sinking|ROKS Cheonan, sank]], near [[Baengnyeong Island]] in the [[Yellow Sea]] and a North Korean torpedo was blamed. On November 23, 2010, in response to a joint military exercise, [[Bombardment of Yeonpyeong|North Korea fired artillery]] at South Korea's Greater Yeonpyeong island in the Yellow Sea, and South Korea returned fire. In 2013, amidst tensions about its missile program, North Korea forced the temporary shutdown of the jointly operated [[Kaesong Industrial Region]].{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/15/world/asia/kaesong-korea-complex-reopens/|title=North and South Korea reopen Kaesong Industrial Complex|author=K .J. Kwon|publisher=CNN|date=16 September 2013|accessdate=17 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140128072041/http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/15/world/asia/kaesong-korea-complex-reopens/|archivedate=28 January 2014|df=}} The zone was shut again in 2016.{{Cite web|title = South Korea to Halt Work at Joint Industrial Park With North|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/south-korea-halt-work-joint-industrial-park-north-korea-n515576|website = NBC News|date = 10 February 2016|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160210110300/http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/south-korea-halt-work-joint-industrial-park-north-korea-n515576|archivedate = 10 February 2016|df = }} A South Korean parliamentarian was convicted of [[2013 South Korean sabotage plot|plotting a campaign of sabotage to support the North in 2013]] and jailed for 12 years.{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2014/02/17/51/0301000000AEN20140217002700315F.html|title=Leftist lawmaker gets 12-year prison term for rebellion plot|publisher=Yonhap News Agency|date=17 February 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222211812/http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2014/02/17/51/0301000000AEN20140217002700315F.html|archivedate=22 February 2014|df=}} In 2014, according to the ''New York Times'', US President [[Barack Obama]] ordered the intensification of [[cyberwarfare|cyber]] and [[electronic warfare]] to disrupt North Korea's missile testing.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/04/world/asia/north-korea-missile-program-sabotage.html|title=Trump Inherits a Secret Cyberwar Against North Korean Missiles|first1=David E|last1=Sanger|first2=William J|last2=Broad|publisher=New York Times|date=4 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170306142900/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/04/world/asia/north-korea-missile-program-sabotage.html|archivedate=6 March 2017|df=}} However, this account has been disputed by analysts from the [[Nautilus Institute for Security and Sustainability|Nautilus Institute]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nknews.org/pro/did-cyber-attacks-slow-down-north-koreas-missile-progress|title=Did cyber attacks slow down North Korea's missile progress?|first1=Markus|last1=Schiller|first2=Peter|last2=Hayes|publisher=NK News|date=9 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170309120535/https://www.nknews.org/pro/did-cyber-attacks-slow-down-north-koreas-missile-progress/|archivedate=9 March 2017|df=}} In 2016, in the face of protests, South Korea decided to deploy the US [[THAAD]] anti-missile system.{{cite news|title=S.Korea to review possible new sites for THAAD deployment|url=https://www.nknews.org/2016/08/s-korea-to-review-possible-new-sites-for-thaad-deployment|first=JH|last=Ahn|publisher=''NK News''|date=22 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822084122/https://www.nknews.org/2016/08/s-korea-to-review-possible-new-sites-for-thaad-deployment/|archivedate=22 August 2016|df=}} After North Korea's [[September 2016 North Korean nuclear test|fifth nuclear test]] in September 2016, it was reported that South Korea had developed a plan to raze Pyongyang if there were signs of an impending nuclear attack from the North.{{cite news|title=S. Korea unveils plan to raze Pyongyang in case of signs of nuclear attack|url=http://m.yna.co.kr/mob2/en/contents_en.jsp?cid=AEN20160911000500315&domain=3&ctype=A&site=0100000000|publisher=''Yonhap News Agency''|date=11 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918080754/http://m.yna.co.kr/mob2/en/contents_en.jsp?cid=AEN20160911000500315&domain=3&ctype=A&site=0100000000|archivedate=18 September 2016|df=}} A North Korean [[numbers station]] started broadcasting again, after a break of 16 years, apparently sending coded messages to agents in the South. As [[2016 South Korean political scandal|South Korea was convulsed by scandal]], North Korea enthusiastically supported the removal of President [[Park Geun-hye]], intensifying leaflet drops.{{cite news|url=https://www.nknews.org/2017/02/graphic-pro-north-korea-leaflets-found-in-downtown-seoul|title=Graphic, pro-North Korea leaflets found in downtown Seoul|first=Chad|last=O'Carroll|publisher=NK News|date=10 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210104731/https://www.nknews.org/2017/02/graphic-pro-north-korea-leaflets-found-in-downtown-seoul/|archivedate=10 February 2017|df=}} In turn, Park's supporters accused the opposition [[Liberty Korea Party]] of basing its logo on Pyongyang's [[Juche Tower]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nknews.org/2017/02/new-south-korean-party-accused-of-using-pyongyangs-juche-tower-as-logo|title=New South Korean party accused of using Pyongyang's Juche Tower as logo|first=JH|last=Ahn|publisher=NK News|date=14 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216134016/https://www.nknews.org/2017/02/new-south-korean-party-accused-of-using-pyongyangs-juche-tower-as-logo|archivedate=16 February 2017|df=}} In March 2017, it was reported that the South Korean government had increased the rewards to [[North Korean defector]]s who brought classified information or military equipment with them.{{cite news|url=https://asiancorrespondent.com/2017/03/south-korea-govt-pay-defectors-north-korea-secrets/#8jmylFYF6gcExTYD.97|title=South Korea: Government to pay defectors for North Korea secrets|publisher=Asian Correspondent|date=5 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170306132526/https://asiancorrespondent.com/2017/03/south-korea-govt-pay-defectors-north-korea-secrets/#8jmylFYF6gcExTYD.97|archivedate=6 March 2017|df=}} It was also reported that in 2016 North Korea hackers had stolen classified South Korean military data, including a plan for the killing of Kim Jong-un. According to cybersecurity experts, North Korea maintained an army of hackers trained to disrupt enemy computer networks and steal both money and sensitive data. In the previous decade, it was blamed for numerous [[cyber-attack]]s and other hacking attacks in South Korea and elsewhere {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/10/world/asia/north-korea-hack-war-plans.html|title=North Korean Hackers Stole U.S.-South Korean Military Plans, Lawmaker Says|first=Choe|last=Sang-hun|publisher=New York Times|date=10 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012061027/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/10/world/asia/north-korea-hack-war-plans.html|archivedate=12 October 2017|df=}}, one of which included a hack of [[Sony Pictures]] over the release of the 2013 film [[The Interview]], which depicts the assassination of Kim Jong-un.{{cite news|last1=Sanger|first1=David E.|last2=Perlroth|first2=Nicole|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/18/world/asia/us-links-north-korea-to-sony-hacking.html?&_r=0|title=U.S. Said to Find North Korea Ordered Cyberattack on Sony|work=The New York Times|date=December 17, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218130909/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/18/world/asia/us-links-north-korea-to-sony-hacking.html?&_r=0|archivedate=December 18, 2014|df=mdy-all}} ==Tension and détente== {{Main|2017–18 North Korea crisis|April 2018 inter-Korean summit|2018 North Korea–United States summit|September 2018 inter-Korean summit}} [[File:2018 inter-Korean summit square.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kim Jong-un]] and [[Moon Jae-in]] shake hands at the Korean DMZ during the [[April 2018 inter-Korean summit|first 2018 inter-Korean summit]]]] [[File:Kim and Trump shaking hands at the red carpet during the DPRK–USA Singapore Summit.jpg|Kim Jong-un and Donald Trump shake hands at the Singapore Summit|thumb|left]] In 2017, the incoming U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] abandoned the policy of "strategic patience" associated with the preceding Obama administration. Later in the year, [[Moon Jae-in]] was elected President of South Korea with a promise to return to the Sunshine Policy.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/south-koreas-likely-next-president-warns-the-us-not-to-meddle-in-its-democracy/2017/05/02/2295255e-29c1-11e7-9081-f5405f56d3e4_story.html|title=South Korea’s likely next president warns the U.S. not to meddle in its democracy|publisher=Washington Post}} On July 4, 2017, North Korea successfully conducted its first test of an [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] (ICBM), named [[Hwasong-14]].{{cite news |title=North Korea Claims Success in Long-Range Missile Test |first1=Sang-hun |last1=Choe |first2= |last2= |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/04/world/asia/north-korea-missile-test-icbm.html |newspaper=The New York Times |location=New York |date=July 4, 2017 |accessdate=July 4, 2017 |page= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170704065145/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/04/world/asia/north-korea-missile-test-icbm.html |archivedate=July 4, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} It conducted another test on July 28.{{cite news |title=North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile, the Pentagon Says |first1=Sang-hun |last1=Choe |first2=Eileen |last2=Sullivan |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/world/asia/north-korea-ballistic-missile.html |newspaper=The New York Times |location=New York |date=July 28, 2017 |accessdate=July 28, 2017 |page= {{italictitle}}'''''Lessons in Love and Violence''''' is an [[opera]] with music by [[George Benjamin (composer)|George Benjamin]] and [[libretto]] by [[Martin Crimp]]. The opera, which is based on the story of [[Edward II of England|King Edward II]] and [[Piers Gaveston]], was premiered at the [[Royal Opera House]] London on 10 May 2018, conducted by the composer and directed by [[Katie Mitchell]]. The opera was a [[co-production (media)|co-production]] with [[Dutch National Opera]], [[Hamburg State Opera]], [[Opéra de Lyon]], [[Lyric Opera of Chicago]], [[Gran Teatre del Liceu]], Barcelona, and [[Teatro Real]], Madrid.[http://www.roh.org.uk/productions/lessons-in-love-and-violence-by-katie-mitchell "Lessons in Love and Violence"], ROH website, accessed 15 May 2018. The opera covers the events set out in [[Christopher Marlowe]]'s play ''[[Edward II (play)|Edward II]]'', which combines the story of Edward and Gaveston (who was murdered in 1312), with the deposition of Edward II by [[Roger Mortimer, 1st Earl of March|Mortimer]] (1327) and the overthrow of Mortimer and Edward's queen [[Isabella of France]] by Edward III (1330).Richard Rowland, "Re-imagining Edward II", Royal Opera House Programme, "Lessons in Love and Violence" (2018), p. 40. The opera is in two parts, of four and three scenes respectively, and is performed without a break.Royal Opera House Programme, "Lessons in Love and Violence" (2018), p.7. King Edward is not referred to by name, only as 'the King'. Similarly his wife Queen Isabella is referred to simply as Isabel, and his son, later [[Edward II of England|Edward III]], is listed as 'Boy, later Young King'. Both Gaveston and Edward's nemesis Mortimer are named. ==Roles== [[File:Edward II - British Library Royal 20 A ii f10 (detail).jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of Edward II being crowned|Edward II shown receiving the English crown in a contemporary illustration]] {| class="wikitable" !Role ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast,
10 May 2018
([[Conducting|Conductor]]: George Benjamin) |- |King |[[baritone]] |[[Stéphane Degout]] |- |Isabel |[[soprano]] |[[Barbara Hannigan]] |- |Gaveston / Stranger |baritone |Gyula Orendt |- |Mortimer |[[tenor]] |Peter Hoare |- |Boy / Young King |tenor |Samuel Boden |- |Girl |silent |Ocean Barrington-Cook |- |Witness 1 / Singer 1 / Woman 1 |soprano |Jennifer France |- |Witness 2 / Singer 2 / Woman 2 |[[mezzo-soprano]] |[[Krisztina Szabó]] |- |Witness 3 / Madman |[[bass-baritone]] |Andri Björn Róbertsson |} ==Synopsis== ===Part One=== Scene 1. Mortimer criticizes the King's obsession with his lover, Gaveston, at a time when his people are suffering from war and starvation. The King strips Mortimer of his wealth and lands. Scene 2. Mortimer impresses on Isabel the King's dereliction of his duties by confronting her with representatives of the suffering people. She agrees to support Mortimer's campaign against Gaveston. Scene 3. Gaveston is arrested during an entertainment at the King's residence. Scene 4. The King rejects Isabel when he hears of Gaveston's death. ===Part Two=== Scene 1. Isabel is now living with Mortimer. They instruct the King's son to assert his royalty by presenting him with a madman who believes that he himself is the true King. Scene 2. The King is in prison. Mortimer persuades him to abdicate. Death, in the guise of Gaveston, claims the King. Scene 3. The King's son, having succeeded to the throne, rejects Isabel and arranges the death of Mortimer. ==Critical reception== The opera received a positive reception in the British press, with some reservations. The review in ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented: "[D]espite the care that has so clearly gone into every aspect of the production, it often seems to be the orchestral music that is really in charge of the drama, as if the usual priorities of opera have been reversed. In the end the terrible story becomes the excuse for some striking music rather than being driven along by it."Andrew Clements, [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/may/11/lessons-in-love-and-violence-review-royal-opera-house-george-benjamin "Lessons in Love and Violence review – soaring tale of a brutal royal downfall"], 11 May 2018, ''Guardian'' website, accessed 16 May 2018. The critic in the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' commented that he " left Covent Garden impressed rather than excited or moved. For all the refinements, Benjamin and Crimp haven’t moved on from ''[[Written on Skin]]'' [their previous opera] so much as shuffled the cards to play the same game." Rupert Christiansen,[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/opera/what-to-see/lessons-love-violence-review-royal-opera-potent-beautiful-account/ "Lessons in Love and Violence review, Royal Opera: a potent and beautiful account of Edward II's downfall"], 11 May 2018, ''Daily Telegraph'' website, accessed 16 May 2018. ''[[The Stage]]'' however praised the opera: "George Benjamin’s new work on the subject of Edward II once again shows his operatic mastery."George Hall,[https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2018/lessons-love-violence-review-royal-opera-house-london/ "Lessons in Love and Violence review at Royal Opera House, London – ‘operatic mastery’"], 11 May 2018, ''The Stage'' website, accessed 16 May 2018. ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:English-language operas]] [[Category:2018 operas]] [[Category:Operas by George Benjamin]] [[Category:Operas based on real people]] [[Category:Opera world premieres at the Royal Opera House]] [[Category:Operas set in England]] [[Category:Operas set in the 14th century]] [[Category:LGBT-related operas]]

[[Second Libyan Civil War (2014–present)|Second Libyan Civil War]] |url= }} The '''Libya Revolutionaries Operations Room''' ([[Abbreviation|abbreviated]] '''LROR'''; {{lang-ar|غرفة عمليات ثوار ليبيا}}) is an armed group loyal to [[Nouri Abusahmain]]. It has been declared a terrorist organization by the [[Council of Deputies|Libyan parliament]]. It is heavily involved in the [[Second Libyan Civil War (2014–present)|Second Libyan Civil War]]. The LROR was established in 2013 by [[Nouri Abusahmain]], who had recently been elected GNC President. He formed the LROR by uniting existing militias under his command. Its official task was to keep order in Tripoli. He allegedly misappropriated 900 million Libyan Dinars (US $720 million) to the benefit of the LROR, but this was not investigated as Abusahmain himself suppressed the inquiry.{{cite book|title=Historical Dictionary of Libya|author=John, R.B.S.|date=2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=9780810878761|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xIrOAwAAQBAJ|page=201|accessdate=2014-10-05}} Soon after being formed, the LROR attempted an Islamist coup when the group [[2013 Libyan coup d'état attempt|kidnapped Prime Minister Ali Zeidan]] in October 2013. The LROR later set up a branch in Benghazi, purportedly to deal with the deteriorating security situation.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=20 May 2014 |title=Guide to key Libyan militias |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19744533 |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }} ==History== ===Formation and kidnapping of Prime Minister Ali Zeidan=== The LROR was created in the fall of 2013 by GNC President [[Nouri Abusahmain]], who tasked it with providing security to Tripoli.{{cite book |last=St John |first=Ronald Bruce |date=4 June 2014 |title=Historical Dictionary of Libya |url= |location= |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |page=201 |isbn= |accessdate= }} The LROR was later involved in the 10 October kidnapping of Prime Minister Ali Zeidan, who it charged with corruption. Zeidan was later rescued the same day after the building where LROR was keeping him was surrounded by a mixture of local protesters and pro-Zeidan militias. ===Attempts to disestablish=== On 27 October 2013, Zeidan supporters walked out of a GNC session in protest to last minute changes to the agenda made by Abusahmain. In the changes Abusahmain cancelled a request by GNC members to disestablish the LROR, and also cancelled a request to establish a committee to investigate the allocation by Abusahmain of 900 million Libyan Dinars ($720 million) to the LROR and various other militias. The GNC members had claimed that the allocations made by Abusahmain had been against GNC rules. On 3 November 2013, the GNC voted to withdraw the LROR's mandate to provide security for Tripoli. In response to the vote LROR forces surrounded the building where the GNC was meeting in an attempt to intimidate members of the GNC. In a compromise vote the GNC agreed to maintain the LROR's mandate for Tripoli, on the terms that the LROR was brought under the control of the General Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces.{{cite book |last=St John |first=Ronald Bruce |date=4 June 2014 |title=Historical Dictionary of Libya |url= |location= |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |page=202 |isbn= |accessdate= }} ==See also== * [[2013 Libyan coup d'état attempt]] * [[2014 Libyan conflict]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{facebook|GTLOfficial}} {{Ar icon}} [[Category:Aftermath of the Libyan Civil War (2011)]] [[Category:Rebel groups in Libya]] {{Libya-stub}}

A '''school prank''' is a [[Practical joke|prank]] primarily occurring in a school setting. The effect and intent of school pranks may range from everyday play and consensual [[Human bonding|bonding]] behavior to [[Crime|crimes]] including [[hazing]], [[School bullying|bullying]] and [[assault]], including [[sexual assault]]. == Common pranks == === Circle game === [[File:Circle_game.jpg|thumb|Example of person playing the circle game]] The objective of the "circle game" or "basic killer"{{cite book |last1=Rohnke |first1=Karl |title=Silver Bullets: A Guide to Initiative Problems, Adventure Games, Stunts and Trust Activities. |date=1984 |publisher=Kendall/Hunt Publishing Company |isbn=9780840356826 |pages=54-55 |url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED356918.pdf |language=en}} [https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED356918 Indexed] at [[ERIC]] to form a circle with one's thumb and forefinger (the [[OK (gesture)|"OK" gesture]]) on the leg below the waist and get someone else to look at it. If the person looks, the gesture-maker gets to hit them, or is simply considered "out" or "killed". In some variations the target can put their index finger through the hole without looking at it and thereby win the right to punch the maker of the gesture.{{cite news|last1=Bish|first1=Joe|title=Searching for the Man Behind 'The Circle Game'|url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/wj8e74/searching-for-the-man-behind-the-circle-game|accessdate=18 January 2018|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|date=29 June 2017|language=en-uk}} ===Pantsing=== {{Main article|Pantsing}} Pantsing (also known as "flagging", "depantsing", "pantsing" and various other names) is the act of pulling down a person's trousers and sometimes also the person's underwear, which reveals the person's [[Sex organ|genitalia]]. The most common method is to sneak up behind the intended victim, grab the waistband of the garment, and apply a quick downward tug before the victim is aware of the debagger's presence. === Flat tire or flat foot === The heel of the victim is trodden upon, which may cause the victim to fall. Stepping on the rear portion of the shoe as the foot lifts and thereby removing it is also a "heels" variant known as a "flat tire" or "score". A variant is to kick their heel forwards as it lifts, known as an "airwalk". === Indian burn === This is a prank done by grasping the victim's forearm firmly in both hands, and then twisting the hands in opposite directions about the victim's arm to stretch their skin, making it red and sore. Known primarily as a "Chinese burn" or a "snake bite" in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Ireland]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]], "buffalo skin" in [[India]], "snake bite", "Chinese Sunburn" or "Indian rub" in [[Canada]], and "Indian burn", "Indian sunburn" or "Indian rug burn" in the [[United States]] (except in some midwest states such as [[Wisconsin]] and [[Illinois]] where it is known as a snakebite), "Indian burn" in [[France]], "policeman's glove" or "hundred needles" in [[Hungary]], "barbed wire" in the [[Netherlands]], "needles" in [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]] and "Brennessel" ("stinging nettle") in [[Austria]], [[Switzerland]] and the southern parts of [[Germany]], "thousand needle stings" in the northern parts of Germany, "manita de puerco" (pork's little hand) in [[Mexico]], "little fire" in the [[Czech Republic]], "thousand needles" in [[Sweden]], "Nettle" in [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]] and [[Russia]], "French cuff" in [[Norway]] and [[Denmark]], "kuuma makkara" (hot sausage) or "nokkonen" (nettle) in [[Finland]] and again "snakebite" in [[Flanders]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}} === Kancho / Dongjim === {{Main article|Kancho}} Kancho is a prank played in [[Japan]];{{cite web|title=Kancho.org|url=http://www.kancho.org/|access-date=2009-04-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201065747/http://www.kancho.org/|archive-date=2009-02-01|dead-url=yes|df=}} it is performed by clasping the hands together so the index fingers are pointing out and attempting to insert them sharply into someone's anal region when the victim is not looking.{{cite web|author=佐藤 信正（さとう　のぶまさ）|url=http://trendy.nikkeibp.co.jp/article/col/20060428/116519/|title=(Japanese) KANCHO across the world in Japan, Korea KANCHO What? ''Trendy Net''|publisher=Trendy.nikkeibp.co.jp|date=|accessdate=2014-07-15}} It is similar to the wedgie or a goosing. Kancho means "[[enema]]". In [[South Korea]] it is known as "ddong-chim" This prank is also played in Scotland, in this case known as a 'fishy' or 'jobbie jab'. In [[Brazil]] is known as Pula Pirata (literally, Jump Pirate), named after the name which the game [[Pop-up Pirate]] is known there. === "Kick me" or other signs === A note (commonly reading "Kick me") is attached to the back of an unsuspecting victim. This prank may be performed with [[Post-it note|Post-it notes]] or other items, such as paper and tape. There are also other signs such as Slap Me or Push Me signs too. === Mooning === {{Main article|Mooning}} "Mooning" is displaying one's bared buttocks to someone, so-called because the buttocks are generally not suntanned, so resemble a full moon. It is commonly performed out of windows of moving buses and cars. === Noogie ===

Sometimes called a ''Monkey Scrub'', ''Hippo Handing'' or ''Russian Haircut'', a noogie is performed when the middle knuckles of the fore and middle fingers are rubbed vigorously against the surface of the scalp, stretching the skin and pulling the hair. A [[Professional wrestling holds#Side headlock|headlock]] may be applied for more exact or prolonged execution. This will trap the victim. The headlock noogie is called "La Savonette du Chef" ("The chief's bath soap") in the area around [[Toulon]], [[France]].

Also described as a 'Skully' in Australian Playgrounds circa 1980's. An open-hand variant known as the Dutch Rub is performed with the heel of the hand. In Czech Republic noogie is called "peanut". === Shoe-lacing === This prank involves the tying of a victim's shoe laces together, typically while the victim is seated and distracted. The laces may also be tied to a nearby object such as a chair leg. This may cause the victim to unexpectedly trip or stumble when attempting to get up and move. This prank may be combined with a taunt or additional prank designed to provoke the victim into getting up and running after the prankster, resulting in a more pronounced effect. A related but more destructive prank involves secretly cutting the shoelaces with scissors. Another variant of this prank involves tying another student's backpack to a table. This is often done at lunch time to cause panic when the bell rings for students to go back to class and the victim only then realizes their predicament. === Short-sheeting/apple-pie bed === [[wikt:apple-pie bed|Apple-pie]] (UK) or [[wikt:shortsheet|short-sheet]] (US) bed is a prank done at boarding schools, college dorms, camps or on excursions where children sleep in full beds (also common in the military services). A [[bed sheet]] is untucked at the head end of the bed and folded, making it look as if it is two sheets (an undersheet and top sheet). The victim will find that he or she cannot get into bed (as doing this "shortens" the bed length). Also known as a 'wallet bed' (''lit en portefeuille'') in France and as an 'apple-pie bed' in the UK.{{Cite book|author=Greg Tananbaum and Dan Martin|title=Atomic Wedgies, Wet Willies, and Other Acts of Roguery|publisher=Santa Monica Press|year=2005|isbn=978-1-59580-000-8}} An apple-pie bed sometimes involves sewing up the sheets with a needle and thread so that it is impossible for the prankee to get in, and requires a degree of effort to make the bed usable again. === Spitball === A "spitball" is a clump of paper that the prankster has chewed and made wet with saliva, to be thrown, spat, or blown at a person or object. If not removed from some types of surface, they dry and harden into a sort of paper cement. Small spitballs are often propelled by placing them in a straw or the shaft of a disassembled hollow pen and blowing through the other end. Larger spitballs are sometimes flicked with the fingers, a flexible ruler or through the use of a rubber band. Sometimes, whole sheets of paper are crumpled and inserted into the mouth for a period of up to five minutes to form a large spitball that is usually thrown manually. === Swirlie === The act of holding the victim upside down and dunking his or her head in a toilet bowl while flushing [[water]]. Instances of swirling have been prosecuted in courts.{{cite news |title=Hazing Investigation|work=[[WTLX]]|format=WMV video|date=2006-04-03|url=http://www.wltx.com/includes/buildasx_oas.aspx?fn=http://wm.wltx.gannett.edgestreams.net//news/apr06/04032006_hazing_wltx.wmv&sp=http://wm.wltx.gannett.edgestreams.net/ads/sales/toyotacenter012307.wmv}} {{Dead link|date=July 2012}} === Towel snap === Also known as a "towel whip", "towel whipping", a "rat-tail", or "rat-tailing", or "kangaroo tail" in Australia, the prankster twists a towel along the diagonal (typically dampened to hold its shape) by spinning it at the corner, making it into a [[whip]] with a towel corner at the tip. The prankster then "snaps" the towel as if cracking a whip, striking the victim with the end tip of the towel and causing pain. This prank is usually performed in communal showers, where wet towels are plentiful and bare skin provides opportunity to maximize the pain inflicted. === Wedgie === {{Main article|Wedgie}} A '''wedgie''' (sometimes also known as a "gotchie" or "grundy" or "melvin" and in instances where the undergarments are torn off, a "Chinese Laundry") is any one of a variety of pranks involving pulling the victim's [[underwear]] up so that it wedges between the [[buttocks]] and may even be performed to the extent that the victim's underpants are torn off. The victim's underwear may also be hung on something in a more extreme form of this prank. A wedgie may be performed by one attacker, or by a group. On April 6, 2006, [[Fox News]] reported on an [[Albany, New York]] teacher who was arrested for endangering the welfare of a child by giving the 10-year-old student a wedgie.{{cite news |title=Charges for Giving a Wedgie|first=Brit|last=Hume|work=Fox News|date=2006-04-06|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,190761,00.html}} === Wet Willy === A prank whereby an assailant moistens one of their fingers with saliva, quietly sneaks up behind a victim and inserts the finger into the victim's ear hole. While the wet willy is primarily an elementary school prank, it is occasionally seen in higher institutions of learning, including the [[Postdoctoral researcher|post doc]] level.{{cite web |author=Via Akifokur1|url=http://www.collegehumor.com/video/6877938/wet-willy-during-proud-moment-for-the-society-of-jesus|title=Wet Willie On the News - CollegeHumor Video|publisher=Collegehumor.com|date=March 15, 2013|accessdate=2014-07-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129112829/http://www.collegehumor.com/video/6877938/wet-willy-during-proud-moment-for-the-society-of-jesus|archivedate=November 29, 2014|df=}} ==See also== * [[List of practical joke topics]] * [[List of hazing deaths in the United States]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{Cite book|author=Steinberg, Neil|title=If at All Possible, Involve a Cow: The Book of College Pranks|location=New York|publisher=St. Martin's Press|year=1992|isbn=0-312-07810-2}} {{Bullying}} [[Category:Harassment]] [[Category:Practical jokes]] [[Category:School bullying]] [[Category:School traditions]]

{{italic title|string=Little Belt}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Little Belt Affair |image=Little_belt_affair.jpg |image_size=300px |caption=A 16 May 1811 engraving shows USS ''President'' battling HMS ''Little Belt'' |partof=the [[Origins of the War of 1812|events]] leading to the [[War of 1812]] |date=16 May 1811 |place=off [[North Carolina]], Atlantic Ocean |result=American victory |combatant1={{flag|United Kingdom}} |combatant2={{flag|United States|1795}} |commander1={{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Arthur Bingham]] |commander2={{flagicon|United States|1795}} [[John Rodgers (1772–1838)|John Rodgers]] |strength1=1 [[sloop-of-war]] |strength2=1 [[frigate]] |casualties1=1 sloop-of-war heavily damaged
11 killed
21 wounded |casualties2=1 frigate slightly damaged
1 wounded |campaignbox= {{Campaignbox |name=Events leading to the War of 1812 |battles={{hlist|[[Chesapeake–Leopard affair|''Chesapeake'' affair]] |'''''Little Belt'' affair'''}} }}}} {{Warof1812-Origins}} The '''''Little Belt'' affair''' was a naval battle on the night of 16 May 1811. It involved the United States [[frigate]] {{USS|President|1800|6}} and the British [[sixth-rate]] {{HMS|Little Belt|1807|6}}, a [[sloop-of-war]], which had originally been the Danish ship ''Lillebælt'', before being captured by the British in the 1807 [[Battle of Copenhagen (1807)|Battle of Copenhagen]]. The encounter took place off the [[North Carolina]] coast. The ''Little Belt'' Affair was one of many incidents and events that led to the [[War of 1812]]. == Background == The ''Little Belt'' affair occurred four years after the [[Chesapeake–Leopard affair|''Chesapeake''–''Leopard'' affair]] of 1807, in which {{HMS|Leopard|1790|6}} had attacked {{USS|Chesapeake|1799|6}}, killing three, wounding eighteen, and putting four of her sailors on trial for desertion. It was fifteen days after an incident involving {{HMS|Guerriere|1806|6}}, a frigate. On 1 May ''Guerriere'' had stopped the [[brig]] {{USS|Spitfire|1803|6}} off [[Sandy Hook]] in [[New Jersey]] and had [[impressment|impressed]] [[Maine]] citizen John Diggio, the apprentice [[sailing master]] of ''Spitfire''. [[Secretary of the Navy]] [[Paul Hamilton (politician)|Paul Hamilton]] had ordered ''President'', along with {{USS|Argus|1803|6}}, to patrol the coastal areas from [[the Carolinas]] to New York. ==The Affair== ===Chase=== [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] [[John Rodgers (1772–1838)|John Rodgers]], commanding the frigate ''President'', had left [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]] several days earlier and was aware of the ''Guerriere'' incident. He was off the Virginia Capes and sailing up the coast towards New York. ''Little Belt'' was sighted to the east at about noon on 16 May. Believing her to be ''Guerriere'', Rodgers pursued. ''Little Belt''{{'}}s captain, [[Arthur Bingham]], had spotted ''President'' one hour earlier. Bingham signaled ''President'' asking for identification but received none. However, he noticed a blue [[Pennant (commissioning)|pennant]] showing the ship's nationality was American. Bingham continued south, but Rodgers continued his pursuit because he wanted to know the stranger's identity. By 15:30, ''President'' was close enough for Rodgers to make out part of the British ship's [[stern]]. However, the angle at which he saw her made her appear larger than she was. ''Little Belt'' was much smaller than ''President'', displacing only 460 tons in contrast to ''President''{{'}}s 1,576. The sloop mounted 20 guns, while ''President'' carried 56. ===Battle=== The British and American accounts disagree on what followed. As ''President'' closed with ''Little Belt'', Bingham thought the frigate was manuevering to rake his ship with gunfire. Bingham [[Jibe|wore ship]] three times to avoid the threat. The ships were not within hailing range until long after sunset. At about 10:15, each captain demanded the other identify his ship. Each refused to answer before the other. Each captain later claimed he had been the first to ask. Shortly after this a shot was fired, but it is disputed who shot it.Toll, Ian W., pp. 321–323. The ships were soon engaged in a battle which the sloop had no chance of winning. After fifteen minutes, most of Bingham's guns had been put out of action, and Rodgers ordered a cease fire. ''President'' returned and Rodgers asked Bingham if he had struck. Bingham replied he had not, and ''President'' withdrew. ==Aftermath== ''President'' had only one man injured. ''Little Belt'' suffered nine dead and 23 injured (two of them fatally). The sloop was also badly damaged in the encounter. The next morning, [[Lieutenant]] John Creighton went from ''President'' to ''Little Belt'' to lament the affair and offer Bingham space at any American port, which he declined. Bingham asked why ''President'' had attacked his much smaller ship. Creighton said it was because ''Little Belt'' had "provoked" the action. Bingham rejected the charge. [[File:President and HMS Little Belt 1811 BRM1682.jpg|thumb|President and HMS Little Belt]] ''President'' sailed on to New York City, and ''Little Belt'' went to the [[North America and West Indies Station|North America Station]] in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], escorted by {{HMS|Goree}} The British and American governments argued about the encounter for months. Rodgers insisted that he had mistaken the sloop for a frigate and was adamant that Bingham had fired first. The [[Admiralty]] expressed their confidence in Bingham and promoted him to [[post-captain]] on 7 February 1812. On 19 August 1812, after war had finally broken out, HMS ''Guerriere'' sailed into her [[USS Constitution vs HMS Guerriere|ill-fated action]] against {{USS|Constitution}}. Painted across her foretopsail were the words "NOT THE LITTLE BELT".Martin, Tyrone G., p. 155.Toll, Ian W., pp. 347–348. ==See also== *[[Timeline of the War of 1812]] *[[Chesapeake–Leopard affair]] == Footnotes == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==References== *{{cite book |title=Six Frigates: The Epic History of the Founding of the U.S. Navy |last=Toll |first=Ian W. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2006 |publisher=W.
