{{Infobox meteor shower | name = Lyrids (LYR) | image = | caption = | pronounce = | date = | parent = [[C/1861 G1 (Thatcher)]] | constellation = [[Lyra ]] ]\]] | ra = {{RA|18|08}} | dec = {{DEC|+32}} | month = {{Nowrap|April 16 – April 25}} | peak = April 22 | velocity = 48 | zhr = 18/hr | notes = }} [[File:Lyrid meteor shower radiant point.jpeg|thumb|Radiant point of the April Lyrid meteor shower, active each year around April 22]] The '''April Lyrids''' (LYR, IAU shower number 6 {{cite web|url=http://www.astro.amu.edu.pl/~jopek/MDC2007/index.php |title=IAU Meteor Data Center|page=1|accessdate=2013-08-06}}) are a [[meteor shower]] lasting from April 16 to April 26{{cite web|url=http://meteorshowersonline.com/lyrids.html |title=Lyrids|publisher=Meteor Showers Online|page=1|accessdate=2008-08-05}} each year. The [[Radiant (meteor shower)|radiant]] of the meteor shower is located in the constellation [[Lyra]], near this constellation's brightest star, Alpha Lyrae (proper name [[Vega]]). Their peak is typically around April 22 each year. The source of the meteor shower is particles of dust shed by the long-period Comet [[C/1861 G1]] Thatcher.{{cite journal | last=Jenniskens | first = P. | title=Meteor Showers and their Parent Comets | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] | date=2006 | pages=790}} The April Lyrids are the strongest annual shower of meteors from debris of a long-period comet, mainly because as far as other intermediate long-period comets go (200–10,000 years), this one has a relatively short orbital period of about 415 years. The Lyrids have been observed and reported since 687 BC; no other modern shower has been recorded as far back in time.{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Bob|title=The Lyrid Shower Kicks Off Year of Great Meteor Watching|url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/observing/lyrid-shower-kicks-off-year-of-great-meteor-watching/|website=www.skyandtelescope.com|publisher=F+W Media, Inc.|accessdate=19 April 2018|date=18 April 2018}} The shower usually peaks on around April 22 and the morning of April 23. Counts typically range from 5 to 20 meteors per hour, averaging around 10. As a result of [[light pollution]], observers in rural areas will see more than observers in a city. Nights without a moon in the sky will reveal the most meteors. April Lyrid meteors are usually around [[Apparent magnitude|magnitude]] +2. However, some meteors can be brighter, known as "Lyrid [[Meteoroid#Fireball|fireballs]]", cast shadows for a split second and leave behind smokey debris trails that last minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceweather.com/meteors/lyrids/lyrids.html|title=the Lyrid meteor shower|date=2008|publisher=spaceweather.com|page=1|accessdate=2008-08-05}} Occasionally, the shower intensifies when the planets steer the one-revolution dust trail of the comet into Earth's path, an event that happens about once every 60 years. This results in an April Lyrid meteor outburst. The one-revolution dust trail is dust that has completed one orbit: the stream of dust released in the return of the comet prior to the current 1862 return.This mechanism replaces earlier ideas that the outbursts were due to a cloud of dust moving in a 60-year orbit.{{cite journal | last=Arter | first=T. R. |author2=Williams, I. P. | title=The mean orbit of the April Lyrids | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | date=1997 | volume=289 | issue=3 | pages=721–728 | bibcode=1997MNRAS.289..721A | doi=10.1093/mnras/289.3.721}} In 1982, amateur astronomers counted 90 April Lyrids per hour at the peak and similar rates were seen in 1922. A stronger storm of up to 700 per hour occurred in 1803, observed by a journalist in [[Richmond, Virginia]]:
Shooting stars. This electrical [sic] phenomenon was observed on Wednesday morning last at Richmond and its vicinity, in a manner that alarmed many, and astonished every person that beheld it. From one until three in the morning, those starry meteors seemed to fall from every point in the heavens, in such numbers as to resemble a shower of sky rockets ...
Another such outburst, and the oldest known, the shower on March 23.7,M. Ed. Biot, 1841, Gatalogue General des Etoiles Filantes et des Autres Meteores Observes en Chine pendent 24 Siecles, Paris, Imprimerie Royale; P. The '''Michigan Festival of Sacred Music''' (MFSM) is a biennial music festival in southwest [[Michigan]] that shares the music of diverse religious traditions.<ref>http://www.mlive.com/kzgazette/answerbook/index.ssf/2009/05/music_concerts_organizations.html Music concerts, organizations add culture to Southwest Michigan - Kalamazoo Gazette, Friday May 15, 2009</ref> The festival occurs during the second weekend in November in odd-numbered years. Events include public concerts and presentations, lectures, and related workshops.
== Mission == The mission of the Michigan Festival of Sacred Music is to present high quality events which represent different religious traditions, promoting mutual respect and understanding through sharing the music treasured by these traditions, and promoting community interaction.
== History == In 1998 the Congregation of the First [[Baptist Church]] of [[Kalamazoo]], Michigan voted to explore the desirability and feasibility of introducing a biennial festival of sacred music into the Kalamazoo Area. With support from the Irving S. Gilmore and [[Kalamazoo Community Foundations]] and input from Kalamazoo-area religious and community leaders, the project got underway in January 1999. An opinion survey to determine its desirability concluded that such a festival is both desirable and feasible. In January 2000 and area-wide representative group met to prepare for its introduction and decided to call it the Michigan Festival of Sacred Music. A Board of Directors was formed with the goal of making the festival a reality in November 2001.
The first full MFSM festival in 2001 was an overwhelming success, and the Michigan Festival of Sacred Music, now an independent organization, has continued planning and presenting the biennial festivals. It is supported by numerous grants and individual contributions, showing the strong support the festival's goals continue to have. It continues to be led by a Board and Advisory Council made up of community leaders and representatives of many different faiths. In 2004, the MFSM presented its first off-season event, which proved to be a great success. The MFSM plans to continue the presentation of single off-season events.
In 2007, the MFSM took over co-sponsorship of the [[Sing-Along Messiah]], shared with [[Congregational church|First Congregational Church]]. This event, which drew over 500 attendees (including about 40 homeless people) in 2007, generally occurs annually on the Sunday following Thanksgiving. In 2007, the MFSM assumed the co-sponsorship role which had previously been taken by the [[Kalamazoo Bach Festival Society]].
As attendance increases with each MFSM, the response from the public and the artists themselves shows that the MFSM provides a much-needed channel for mutual understanding of diverse religious traditions and cultures. The first festival, occurring as it did soon after the 2001 terrorist attacks, had a powerful healing quality. As our community continues to try to make sense of events unfolding on the world stage, we find the subsequent festivals to be as meaningful as the first. The high quality of the performing artists and programming makes the festivals valuable aesthetic experiences, as well.
== External links == *[http://www.mfsm.us/ Michigan Festival of Sacred Music]

'''NGOM Fest''' is a music festival established in [[Prizren]], [[Kosovo]]. The word "Ngom" is written in ''[[Gheg Albanian]]'' dialect and it means "Listen to me" whereas the word "Fest" represents the abbreviation of the word "Festival". This Festival originates from a group of young and creative people who are active in the social life of ''[[Prizren]]'' and ''[[Kosovo]]''. The first edition of the festival was held in June 2011 and due to its major success, the activists were more committed in organizing this event. The main objectives of this festival are to promote new bands and artists, build a new perspective for music festivals in Kosovo, and to connect different ethnic groups in ''[[Kosovo]]'' and in the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southeast-europe.eu/index.php?id=1884 |title=Southeast Europe: People and Culture: NGOM Festival |publisher=Southeast-europe.eu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-06}}</ref><ref name="ngomfest1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ngomfest.com/2013/?id=festivali&gjuha=1 |accessdate=March 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710072640/http://ngomfest.com/2013/?id=festivali&gjuha=1 |archivedate=July 10, 2013 }}</ref>
== History == The first edition of the festival took place on June 24, 2011. The success that this festival had in its first year had set a solid base for the future editions. This achievement helped promote cultural inheritance including the sightseeing's of Prizren, qualitative music and aided to raise awareness of environmental issues. At the same time, numerous events concerning different social and cultural issues were held during the course of three days of this festival. The main focus was to address problems that preoccupy the youth and the society in general. During the first edition, this festival was awarded by the Municipality of Prizren with the prize “The Most Massive Event of the Year 2011".<ref name="ngomfest1"/>
The second edition of the festival took place on June 22, 2012. It lasted three days and had six stages. These stages included "Shatervan" stage, "Parkingu" stage, "Marash" stage, "Ngom Cafe" stage, "Promo" Stage and "Classical Music" stage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Time Magazine |url=http://www.demotix.com/photo/1294135/ngom-fest-held-prizren |title=Ngom Fest held in Prizren |publisher=Demotix.com |date=2012-06-23 |accessdate=2015-05-06}}</ref> The activities that were held during the duration of NGOM Fest included Photography exhibition, Workshop for Recycling, Workshop Drums Clinic, Disc Collections - The Old time Music, The city of bicycles, Exhibition with ecycled objects, Cleaning the city and planting seeds, NGOM Caffe, NGOM Shop and NGOM Camp. During the second edition, this festival was awarded by the Municipality of Prizren with the prize "The Event of the Year".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pinvents.com/event/187134898079505/ngom-fest-2012 |title=NGOM Fest 2012 - Prizren |publisher=Pinvents.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-06}}</ref>
The third edition of NGOM Fest took place in Prizren during a course of three days, from 5 to 7 July 2013. The main focus of 2013’s NGOM Fest edition was electronic music such as ''[[drum and bass]]'', ''[[dubstep]]'', progressive techno, ''[[trip hop]]'', ''[[break (music)|break]]'' and ''[[rock music|rock]]'' genres such as ''[[heavy metal music|heavy metal]]'' and ''[[punk rock]]''. More than 30 music bands performed in this edition, among them the Turkish band ''[[Baba Zula]]'', known for combining traditional Turkish instruments with electronic and reggae instruments. Other artists who performed in NGOM Fest include, [[Lenzman]], the famous Dutch DJ and producer performed drum and bass music and the Kosovar rock band [[Troja (band)|Troja]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegrafi.com/magazina/behuni-gati-te-ngoni-ngom-fest-6-19307.html |title=Bëhuni gati të ‘ngoni’ NGOM Fest |publisher=Telegrafi.com |date=2013-06-28 |accessdate=2015-05-06}}</ref>
== The Festival == {{local|date=September 2014}} The opening ceremony of the festival starts at 19:00. During this show, secondary school pupils from Kosovo and students of the “Academy of Music in Prishtina” performed classical music. After 20:00 the music starts at the stage in “Marash” and also in the stage of “Shadërvan.” The music continues until the last day at noon. Another scene that is part of NGOM Fest is the‘Promo Scene’ which is designed to promote new musical bands. Thirty bands from Kosova and Albania applied to perform, however only 10 bands were accepted, amongst them, three bands will be selected to record a song in a studio. This activity aims to promote and support the early careers of these new bands. Eighty volunteers participate in the organization of this festival, by turning Prizren into a city of music and art for three days in a row. The camp in Prizren is located in the center of the city, near the Bistrica. This camp accommodates visitors from all over the countries and houses them at the lowest price.
Besides the music performances, this festival is known for recreational spots, including the Ngom Shop. Another interesting event which takes place during these three days is the exhibition that presents the most beautiful parts of the city and its architecture. This exhibition is placed in Hamam. The food is another exciting part of this musical festival since it represents the traditional cuisine of Prizren and the Albanian culture in general.
== Bands and artists == Music in NGOM Fest consists of a variety of genres. Starting from classical music, rock, alternative, pop and including the latest electronic music hits. Separate and different-themed stages were set up for each music genre. Notable performing bands and artists in this festival include: Jericho, Dark Angel, Son of Beat & Japan from Serbia, Bojken Lako from Albania, Jim Rivers from Ukraine, Conquering Lion from the Republic of Macedonia, Filip Motovunski from Croatia, Quantized Music from Greece, Gillespie, Alley Sin from Bulgaria, [[Triko]], [[Troja (band)|Troja]], Peni Trio, Jimmy Hagan, Pink Metal, Owlie and many more.

The '''Newport Beach Wooden Boat Festival''' is an annual event held at the [[Balboa Yacht Club]] in [[Newport Beach, California]]. The festival celebrates wooden boats of all sizes including wooden [[canoes]], [[kayaks]], and [[dinghies]], as well as [[yachts]] and [[tall ships]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://bycwoodenboatfestival.com/|title = BYC Wooden Boat Festival|website = BYC Wooden Boat Festival|language = en-US|access-date = 2016-04-18}}</ref>
The first Newport Beach Wooden Boat Festival was held June 6, 2014 and featured 47 boats on display.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.newportbeach.com/events/1st-annual-wooden-boat-festival-balboa-yacht-club/|title = Wooden Boat Festival at Balboa Yacht Club|website = Newport Beach Chamber of Commerce|language = en-US|access-date = 2016-04-18}}</ref>
==Awards== Awards are given in the following categories:
* Best–in-class power: over 50 feet and under 50 feet * Best–in-class sail: over 50 feet and under 50 feet * Human-powered wooden vessels
==2015 events==
The 2105 Newport Beach Wooden Boat Festival was held on June 6, 2015, in conjunction with the 40th anniversary of the Newport Beach Harbor Patrol.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://bycwoodenboatfestival.com/40-year-open-house-oc-sheriff-harbor-patrol/|title = 40 Year Open House – OC Sheriff Harbor Patrol|website = BYC Wooden Boat Festival|language = en-US|access-date = 2016-04-18}}</ref> The yacht ''[[America (yacht)|America]]'', for which the [[America's Cup]] is named, was on display at the event.<ref>http://bycwoodenboatfestival.com/yacht-america/</ref>
==2014 Winners== Sail: * Over 50 feet: [[Zapata II]] * Under 50 feet: [[RHODES 33]] "Madness"

[[Image:Capucins.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Les Capucins]]
'''Opéra de Baugé''' is an [[opera festival]] held each summer near the [[Loire Valley|Loire]] town of [[Baugé-en-Anjou]], 40 kilometres east of [[Angers]], [[France]].
From 2003 to 2011 the festival was held in the gardens of Les Capucins (pictured), a private house and former convent. In 2016 the festival returned to Les Capucins after 4 years in a theatre in the centre of the town.
The festival is modelled on England's [[Glyndebourne Festival Opera]], and performances feature 90-minute intervals during which members of the audience picnic or dine in the attached restaurant. Many of the cast and orchestra are English, and the performances are [[Surtitles|surtitled]] in both English and French. In recent years the festival has drawn an audience of 2,500-3,000 to the town, including large numbers who travel from England.
The 2016 season featured performancesof [[L'incoronazione di Poppea]] ([[Claudio Monteverdi|Monteverdi]]), [[Albert Herring]] ([[Benjamin Britten|Britten]]) and [[La Périchole]] ([[Jacques Offenbach|Offenbach]]). The works presented in 2017 are [[Lucia di Lammermoor]] ([[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]]), [[La Cenerentola]] ([[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]]) and [[La clemenza di Tito]] ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]).
The opera is noted for its authentic performances, with a full orchestra and chorus in support of fully staged productions. The festival has increasingly attracted soloists from across Europe and beyond. Singers have gone on to win prizes including the [[Kathleen Ferrier Award]] and positions in the Young Artists Programme at [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]].
Bernadette Grimmett has been artistic director of the festival since its inception.

{{Infobox play | name = Orson's Shadow | image = OrsonsShadow.jpg | alt = Orson's Shadow art | caption = Poster art from the off-Broadway production | writer = [[Austin Pendleton]] | chorus = | characters = | mute = | setting = | premiere = {{Start date|2000|01}} | place = [[Steppenwolf Theatre Company]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''Orson's Shadow''''' is a play by [[Austin Pendleton]]. The play received a [[Lucille Lortel]] Award nomination for Outstanding Play and won the [[Drama League Award]] for Distinguished Performance.
==Plot== The play, based on true events, is set in 1960 [[London]]. In his declining years, [[Orson Welles]] is directing a production of [[Eugène Ionesco]]'s ''[[Rhinoceros (play)|Rhinoceros]]'', starring [[Laurence Olivier]] and [[Joan Plowright]]. Olivier is fresh from his triumphant theatrical portrayal of [[Vaudeville|vaudevillian]] Archie Rice and is about to reprise the role in the film adaptation of [[John Osborne]]'s ''[[The Entertainer (film)|The Entertainer]]''. He and Plowright are in the early stages of a romantic liaison; Olivier's tumultuous marriage to [[Vivien Leigh]] is all but ended. Critic [[Kenneth Tynan]] also figures in the plot, which debates the merits of stage versus screen, the internal struggle that theatrical performers endure when contemplating a leap to films, and the ways that the studio system frustrated the careers of individual artists.
It is a study of theatrical egos, each of the protagonists living more on the stage than in real life, each one feeling insecure while jockeying for power.
== Production history == ===United States=== The play debuted at the [[Steppenwolf Theatre]] in [[Chicago]] in January 2000 and was performed at the [[Old Globe Theatre]] in [[San Diego]] in September of that year.<ref>Citron, Cynthia. [http://www.curtainup.com/orsonsshadow.html Orson's Shadow Review], Curtain Up. 2008</ref>
The [[off-Broadway]] production, directed by [[David Cromer]], opened on March 13, 2005 at the [[Barrow Street Theatre]], where it ran for 349 performances. The cast included Jeff Still as Orson Welles, John Judd as Laurence Olivier, Susan Bennett as Joan Plowright, Lee Roy Rogers as Vivien Leigh, [[Tracy Letts]] as Ken Tynan, and Ian Westerfer as the stagehand Sean.
Since its [[New York City]] staging, ''Orson's Shadow'' has been mounted by a number of [[Regional theatre in the United States|regional theatre]]s, including [[Marin Theatre Company]] in [[Mill Valley, California]],<ref>[http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/sanfran/s828.html Talking Broadway]</ref> Round House Theatre in [[Bethesda, Maryland]],<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/07/AR2007020702520.html Washington Post] 2007</ref> Unicorn Theatre in [[Kansas City, Missouri]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infozine.com/news/stories/op/storiesView/sid/18574/|title=Orson's Shadow at the Unicorn Theatre, a Review - Kansas City infoZine|work=Kansas City infoZine|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> and the Gorilla Theatre in [[Tampa, Florida]].<ref>Fleming, John. [http://www.sptimes.com/2007/03/01/news_pf/Weekend/When_the_stars_start_.shtml When the Stars Start to Dim] March 1st, 2007</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In 2006 it received a rehearsed reading at London's [[Old Vic|Old Vic Theatre]], and in July 2015 received its European premiere directed by Alice Hamilton at London's [[Southwark Playhouse]], as part of the Orson Welles centenary. The cast included John Hodgkinson as Orson Welles, [[Adrian Lukis]] as Laurence Olivier, Louise Ford as Joan Plowright, [[Gina Bellman]] as Vivien Leigh, [[Edward Bennett (actor)|Edward Bennett]] as Kenneth Tynan, and Ciaran O'Brien as the stagehand Sean.<ref>Stratford, Brice. [http://www.wellesnet.com/review-orsons-shadow-makes-its-european-debut/ 'Orson's Shadow' Makes it's European Debut], Wellesnet. July 8th, 2015</ref>

[[File:Cook Island dancers at Auckland's Pacifica festival.jpg|thumb|Dancers at the Cook Islands stage, 2010]] The '''Pasifika Festival''' is a [[Pacific Islands]]-themed festival held annually in [[Western Springs]], [[Auckland City]], [[New Zealand]]. Celebrated since 1993, it is the largest festival of its type in the world and attracts over 225,000 visitors every year.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10496916">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/multiculturalism/news/article.cfm?c_id=58&objectid=10496916 |title=Thousands attend Pasifika |author=Tapaleao, Vaimoana |date=8 March 2008 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>
The event is owned and hosted by [[Auckland Council]].
The festival presents a wide variety of cultural experiences, including traditional cuisine and performances from [[Samoa]], [[Tonga]], [[Cook Islands]], [[Fiji]], [[Niue]], [[Tahiti]], [[Tokelau]], [[Tuvalu]], [[Kiribati]] and the [[Tangata Whenua]] (New Zealand Maori).
Pasifika Festival 2014 had 11 unique villages showcasing the cultures of 11 Pacific Island nations: [[Cook Islands]], [[Fiji]], [[Hawaii]], [[Kiribati]], [[Niue]], [[Samoa]], [[Tahiti]], [[Tonga]], [[Tokelau]], [[Tuvalu]] and [[Aotearoa]]. <ref>Pasifika Festival 2014 website | http://pasifika.aucklandnz.com/pasifika</ref>
In 2015, the festival was moved temporarily to Hayman Park in [[Manukau]] after the discovery of [[Bactrocera tryoni|Queensland fruit flies]] in the [[Grey Lynn]] area near Western Springs.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fruit fly war: Pasifika festival forced to move|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=11407888|accessdate=15 March 2015|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=25 February 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, it moved back to Western Springs. <ref>Pasifika to go back to Western Springs | https://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/manukau-courier/70368809/pasifika-to-go-back-to-western-springs</ref>
[[Image:Niuean dancing.jpg|thumb|[[Niue|Niuean]] dancers at the Pasifika Festival (2002).]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox television episode | title = Red Museum | series = [[The X-Files]] | season = [[The X-Files (season 2)|2]] | episode = 10 | airdate = December 9, 1994 | production = 2X10 | writer = [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]] | director = Win Phelps | guests = * [[Paul Sand]] as Gerd Thomas * [[Steve Eastin]] as Sheriff Mazeroski * [[Mark Rolston]] as Richard Odin * [[Lindsey Ginter]] as [[Men in Black (The X-Files)#The Cleaner/Crew Cut Man|Crew Cut Man]]<ref name="plot1"/> | length = 45 minutes | prev = [[Firewalker (The X-Files)|Firewalker]] | next = [[Excelsis Dei]] | season_article = The X-Files (season 2) | episode_list = List of The X-Files episodes }} "'''Red Museum'''" is the tenth episode of the [[The X-Files (season 2)|second season]] of the [[science fiction]] [[television series]] ''[[The X-Files]]''. It premiered on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] on December 9, 1994. It was written by [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]], directed by Win Phelps, and featured guest appearances by [[Mark Rolston]], [[Paul Sand]], [[Bob Frazer]], and [[Robert Clothier]]. The episode helps to explore the series' overarching [[Mythology of The X-Files|mythology]]. "Red Museum" earned a Nielsen household rating of 10.4, being watched by 9.9 million households in its initial broadcast. The episode received mixed to negative reviews from critics, with many noting the episode's complexity as a detractor.
The show centers on [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] special agents [[Fox Mulder]] ([[David Duchovny]]) and [[Dana Scully]] ([[Gillian Anderson]]) who work on cases linked to the paranormal, called [[X-File]]s. In the episode, Mulder and Scully travel to Wisconsin after several teens are found wandering in the woods in their underwear with “He Is One” or “She Is One” scrawled on their backs. However, the duo soon stumble upon a strange cult of vegetarian “walk-ins.”
Originally, the episode was slated to be a crossover episode with the [[CBS]] show ''[[Picket Fences]]''. However, the networks nixed the idea before any filming could begin. A facet of the episode, that the adherents of the Red Museum believe that the year 2012 will bring about the dawning of The New Age, is later referenced in the series' finale "[[The Truth (The X-Files)|The Truth]]", seven seasons later.
== Plot ==
[[Fox Mulder]] and [[Dana Scully]] are called in to investigate a number of kidnappings in [[Wisconsin|Delta Glen, Wisconsin]] where local teenagers are recovered half-naked and drugged with either the phrase "He is one" or "She is one" written on their backs. Meeting with Sheriff Mazeroski, the agents initially suspect a nearby [[cult]], the Church of the Red Museum, which was founded by [[vegetarian]] Richard Odin. Mulder, Scully and Mazeroski attend a ceremony of the Red Museum, causing Mulder to believe that they are [[walk-in]]s, people whose souls have been taken over by someone else. One of the kidnap victims claims to have felt an animal spirit enter him.
Katie, the girlfriend of Mazeroski's son Rick, is the latest to be found, and her blood is found to contain an unknown alkaloid substance and high levels of [[Hyoscine hydrobromide|scopolamine]], a controlled substance. This appears to link her to Odin, a former doctor. Meanwhile, the agents meet an old man who points to a pair of men injecting growth serum into cattle, which he believes is the cause of the trouble. That night, local doctor Jerrold Larson is killed in a plane crash. An investigation of the site turns up shipping orders that trace back to the kidnapped teens. One of the men injecting the cows is murdered by the [[Men in Black (The X-Files)#The Cleaner/Crew Cut Man|Crew Cut Man]]. The other, a [[Voyeurism|peeping tom]] named Gerd Thomas, is revealed to be the kidnapper after the agents find a hidden supply of videotapes in the home of one of the victims. Thomas claims that Larson had been turning the children into "monsters" with the drugs he had been injecting in them, which he claims to be unknown.
Meanwhile, Rick is murdered by the Crew Cut Man. Having passed by him on the road, Scully recognizes him as the assassin who killed [[Deep Throat (The X-Files)|Deep Throat]]. Her toxicology results on the victims show what she thinks is the mysterious substance known as "Purity Control". Mulder theorizes that Larson had been injecting the children with alien [[DNA]], and convinces Mazeroski to round up all of the children who had been receiving treatment from Larson and hide them in the Church of the Red Museum. Mulder tracks the Crew Cut Man down at a beef processing plant that he is about to destroy. While Mulder wants him alive, Mazeroski kills him as revenge for Rick's murder and Deep Throat’s murder as well.
Scully reports that the Crew Cut Man had no records on file with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] or other agencies. The material injected into the cows and children is found to be an unknown substance. All the children who were inoculated came down with a flu-like illness while those in the Church of the Red Museum did not, causing her to think they were a [[control group]]. Scully declares the case open and unsolved.<ref name="plot1">Lowry, pp. 184–185</ref><ref name="plot2">Lovece, pp. 133–135</ref>
==Production==
[[File:Michelle Pfeiffer and David E. Kelley.jpg|right|150px|David E. Kelley (''left''), series creator of ''Picket Fences'' initially wanted to make "Red Museum" a crossover|thumb]]
The original draft of "Red Museum" function as a [[Fictional crossover|crossover]] episode with the [[CBS]] show ''[[Picket Fences]]''{{em dash}}an idiosyncratic [[CBS]] drama that ran from 1992 until 1996 and was set in the fictional Wisconsin town of Rome.<ref name="picketfences" /><ref name=poobala>{{cite web|last=Natale|first=Richard|title='Fences' X'd Out|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,304822,00.html|date=9 December 1994|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref> This idea came about when [[David E. Kelley]] (the series creator of ''Picket Fences'') and [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]] (the series creator of ''The X-Files'') were talking in a parking lot about how interesting it would be to have Mulder and Scully visit Rome.<ref name="poobala"/>
Kelley and Carter started to plan out ideas, agreeing that unlike traditional crossovers, the two shows would each air their own episode, featuring characters from the other series.<ref name="poobala"/> However, CBS vetoed the crossover idea.<ref name="picketfences">Lowry, p. 185</ref> Executive producer [[R.W. Goodwin|Robert Goodwin]] said of the experience: "I spent days on the phone with a producer of ''Picket Fences''. We spent days organizing our schedules. Then at the very last minute, of course, we found out that no one had told CBS, and they said 'Forget it. We're having enough trouble on Friday nights without publicizing ''[[The X-Files]]''.' It's too bad."<ref name="prod1">Edwards, p. 108</ref> The ''Picket Fences'' episode originally intended to crossover with ''The X-Files'' was called "Away in the Manger" and aired the week following "Red Museum." While every reference to ''Picket Fences'' was purged from ''The X-Files'' episode, the ''Picket Fences'' episode contains a few subtle references to the happenings in "Red Museum", including a mention of Dr. Larson.<ref name="poobala"/>
Producer and writer [[Glen Morgan]] was disappointed with how the Crew Cut Man was killed off in the episode, saying, "My feeling is that to bring this guy back, his presence should have been better developed, and he's shot off screen. I thought 'Geez, this is the guy who killed Deep Throat, who the audience loved, and it's kind of tossed away.' The episode just seems like half of one thing for a while, then half of something else. I think that was a curious choice for Chris [Carter]. He wanted to take a real left turn, but I'd rather have seen a whole episode about that guy showing up and Mulder getting back at him."<ref name="rec1" /> Morgan's writer partner [[James Wong (producer)|James Wong]] disliked the episode, saying, "I think that was one of the most confusing episodes I've ever seen. It had some really neat ideas in it, but I don't think it pulled together finally."<ref name="rec1">Edwards, p. 107</ref>
[[Ladner, British Columbia]] served as a location for Delta Glen, while the beef processing plant was shot in a facility in [[Cloverdale, British Columbia|Cloverdale]]; local employees at the latter were even used as extras in the butchering and cleaning up scenes.<ref>Gradnitzer and Pittson, pp. 66-9</ref> The episode is the first in the series to mention the concept of walk-ins, a plot device that would later be used [[The X-Files (season 7)|five seasons later]], when [[Closure (The X-Files)|the truth about Samantha's abduction]] was finally revealed.<ref>Hurwitz and Knowles, p. 58</ref>
==Broadcast and reception==
"Red Museum" premiered on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] on December 9, 1994.<ref name="dvdliner">{{cite DVD notes |title=The X-Files: The Complete Second Season |titlelink=The X-Files (season 2) |origyear=1994–1995 |others=[[David Nutter]], [[Daniel Sackheim]], et al |type=booklet |publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Corporation|Fox]] }}</ref> This episode earned a [[Nielsen rating]] of 10.4, with an 18 share, meaning that roughly 10.4 percent of all television-equipped households, and 18 percent of households watching television, were tuned in to the episode. It was viewed by 9.9 million households.<ref name="rating">Lowry, p. 249</ref>
The episode received mostly mixed to negative reviews from critics. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave "Red Museum" a B, noting that the episode was "creative if convoluted."<ref name="EW">{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,295179_2,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219004834/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C295179_2%2C00.html |archive-date=19 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |title=X Cyclopedia: The Ultimate Episode Guide, Season 2 {{!}} EW.com |publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' |date=29 November 1996 |accessdate=19 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> Reviewer Zack Handlen of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' criticized the way "Red Museum" was written, writing that the episode, "tries the neat trick of combining what appears to be a [Monster-of-the-Week] ep with mythos; the results are intriguing, but not entirely successful."<ref name=avclub/> He concluded that the episode was "good" but ultimately "forgettable."<ref name=avclub>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/red-museumexcelsis-deiaubrey,13160/|first=Zack|last=Handlen|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|title=Red Museum/Excelsis Dei/Aubrey|date=5 September 2008|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref> Critical Myth's John Keegan gave the episode 5/10, criticizing the complexity of the plot.<ref name=myth/> He wrote that "Fairly quickly, ''The X-Files'' gained a reputation for episodes that were so convoluted and confusing that few people could make sense of them. This episode stands as one of the shining examples of that trend, and it’s only appropriate that the episode was written by Chris Carter."<ref name=myth>{{cite news | url=http://www.entil2001.com/series/x-files/reviews/season2/2-10.html | title=Red Museum|last=Keegan|first=John | publisher=Critical Myth | accessdate=18 December 2011 }}</ref>

page.title: Religious interpretations of the Big Bang theory

revision.text:
{{ cosmology |expanded=history}} Since the emergence of the [[Big Bang theory]] as the dominant [[physical cosmology|physical cosmological paradigm]], there have been a variety of reactions by religious groups regarding its implications for [[religious cosmology|religious cosmologies]]. Some accept the scientific evidence at face value, some seek to harmonize the Big Bang with their religious tenets, and some reject or ignore the evidence for the Big Bang theory.<ref> {{cite web |last=Wright |first=E.L |date=24 May 2009 |title=Cosmology and Religion |url=http://www.astro.ucla.edu/~wright/cosmo-religion.html |work=Ned Wright's Cosmology Tutorial |accessdate=2009-10-15}} </ref>
==Background== The Big Bang itself is a [[scientific theory]] and as such stands or falls by its agreement with [[observation]]s.<ref name="Kragh">{{cite book | author = Kragh, Helge | title = Cosmology and Controversy | publisher = Princeton University Press | date = 1996 | isbn=0-691-00546-X | page={{page needed|date=February 2012}}}}</ref> However, as a theory which addresses the nature of the universe since its earliest discernible existence, the Big Bang carries possible theological implications regarding the concept of creation [[Ex nihilo|out of nothing]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Philosophy of Physics|pages=1183–1285|title=Issues in the philosophy of cosmology|doi=10.1016/B978-044451560-5/50014-2|author=George F R Ellis|date=2007-08-08|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780444515605500142|isbn=9780444515605|arxiv=astro-ph/0602280}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0370-2693(82)90866-8 | issn = 0370-2693 | volume = 117 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 25–28 | last = Alexander | first = Vilenkin | title = Creation of universes from nothing | journal = Physics Letters B | accessdate = 2012-02-28 | date = 1982-11-04 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0370269382908668 | bibcode = 1982PhLB..117...25V }}</ref><ref name="Manson - Theological Implications"> {{cite book |last=Manson |first=N.A. |date=1993 |title=God and Design: The Teleological Argument and Modern Science |url=https://books.google.com/?id=zCx4rICgN_EC&pg=PA277 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |quote=The Big Bang theory strikes many people as having theological implications, as shown by those who do not welcome those implications. |isbn=978-0-415-26344-3 }}</ref> Many atheist philosophers have argued against the idea of the Universe having a beginning - the Universe might simply have existed for all eternity, but with the emerging evidence of the Big Bang theory, many theologians and physicists have viewed it as implicating [[theism]];<ref> {{cite book |first=J.F. |last=Harris |title=Analytic Philosophy of Religion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rx2Qf9ieFKYC&pg=PA129 |date=2002 |isbn=978-1-4020-0530-5 |quote=Both theists and physicists have seen the big bang theory as leaving open such an opportunity for a theistic explanation. |publisher=[[Springer Press]] }}</ref><ref name="Lerner - Theological Implications">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IwNVDMOgQRQC&pg=PT469 |title =The Big Bang Never Happened: A Startling Refutation of the Dominant Theory of the Origin of the Universe|author=Eric J. Lerner|author-link=Eric J. Lerner|publisher=[[Vintage Books]]|quote=From theologians to physicists to novelists, it is widely believed that the Big Bang theory supports Christian concepts of a creator. In February 1989, for example, the front-page article of the ''New York Times Book Review'' argued that scientists argued that scientists and novelists were returning to God, in large part through the influence of the Big Bang.|accessdate = 2012-03-16|isbn=9780307773548|date=2010-12-15}}</ref> a popular philosophical argument for the [[existence of God]] known as the [[Kalam cosmological argument]] rests in the concepts of the Big Bang.<ref>{{cite book |author=James Franklin Harris |date=2002 |title=Analytic Philosophy of Religion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rx2Qf9ieFKYC&pg=PA129 |quote=THE KALAM COSMOLOGICAL ARGUMENT Perhaps the best known and most clearly formulated version of the cosmological argument that incorporates the fundamental concepts of big bang theory is found in the work of William Lane Craig. |publisher=[[Springer Science]] |isbn=9781402005305 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=A.E. |last=McGrath |author-link=Alister E. McGrath |date=2011 |title=Science and Religion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i3b-A7g6Nq4C&pg=PT57 |quote=It will be clear that this type of argument relates directly to modern cosmological research, particularly the "big bang" theory of the origins of the cosmos. This is also true of the ''kalam'' version of the cosmological argument, to which we now turn. |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |isbn=978-1-4443-5808-7 }}</ref> In the 1920s and 1930s almost every major cosmologist preferred an eternal [[Steady state theory|steady state]] Universe, and several complained that the beginning of time implied by the Big Bang imported religious concepts into physics; this objection was later repeated by supporters of the steady state theory,<ref> {{cite book |last=Kragh |first=H. |date=1996 |title=Cosmology and Controversy |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |location=Princeton (NJ) |isbn=0-691-02623-8 }}</ref> who rejected the implication that the universe had a beginning.<ref name="Cambridge - Theological Implications"> {{cite book |first=P. |last=Harrison |date=2010 |title=The Cambridge Companion to Science and Religion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0mSCHC0QMUgC&dq=%22a+proposition+that+for+some+had+unwelcome+religious+implications%22+%22initial+resistance+to+the+Big+Bang+theory+was+that+unlike+the+rival+Steady+State+hypothesis+it+proposed+that+the+universe+has+a+beginning%22&q=%22a+proposition+that+for+some+had+unwelcome+religious+implications%22+%22initial+resistance+to+the+Big+Bang+theory+was+that+unlike+the+rival+Steady+State+hypothesis+it+proposed+that+the+universe+has+a+beginning%22#v=snippet&q=%22a%20proposition%20that%20for%20some%20had%20unwelcome%20religious%20implications%22%20%22initial%20resistance%20to%20the%20Big%20Bang%20theory%20was%20that%20unlike%20the%20rival%20Steady%20State%20hypothesis%20it%20proposed%20that%20the%20universe%20has%20a%20beginning%22&f=false |quote=One reason for initial resistance to the Big Bang theory was that, unlike the rival Steady-State hypothesis, it proposed that the universe has a beginning – a proposition that for some had unwelcome religious implications. |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-71251-4 |page=9}}</ref><ref name="Helge Kragh - Speech">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GB3Zst_4HLsC&pg=PA226 |title =Entropic Creation |first=H. |last=Kragh |publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]] |date=2008 |isbn=978-0-7546-6414-7 |page=226 |quote=Andrei Zhdanov, Stalin's notorious chief ideologue, said in a speech of 1947 that Lemaître and his kindred spirits were 'Falsifiers of science [who] wanted to revive the fairy tale of the origin of the world from nothing ... Another failure of the 'theory' in question consists in the fact that it brings us to the idealistic attitude of assuming the world to be finite.' }}</ref>
==Hinduism== The view from the [[Hindu]] ''[[Puranas]]'' is that of an eternal universe cosmology, in which time has no absolute beginning, but rather is infinite and cyclic, rather than a universe which originated from a Big Bang.<ref name="SanatanDharma1"> {{cite book |author=Sushil Mittal |author2=G. R. Thursby |date=2004 |title=The Hindu World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fz6KBkgEacAC&pg=PA284&dq=hindu+big+bang#v=onepage&q=hindu%20big%20bang&f=false |publisher=[[Psychology Press]] |quote=In the Vedic cosmogonies, the question of what caused the primordial desire does not arise; like the Big Bang of modern cosmology, the primal impulse is beyond all time and causation, so it makes no sense to ask what preceded it or what caused it. However, in the Hindu cosmology which we find in the Puranas and other non-Vedic Sanskrit texts, time has no absolute beginning; it is infinite and cyclic and so is ''kama''.}}</ref><ref name="SanatanDharma2"> {{cite book |author=John R. Hinnells |date=2010 |title=The Routledge companion to the study of religion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RyuJ_BfJki8C&pg=PA118&dq=hindu+big+bang+eternal+universe#v=onepage&q=hindu%20big%20bang%20eternal%20universe&f=false|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |quote=There are also other cosmological models of the universe besides the Big bang model, including eternal universe theories – views more in keeping with Hindu cosmologies than with traditional theistic concepts of the cosmos. |isbn=0415473284}}</ref> However, the ''Encyclopædia of Hinduism'', referencing ''[[Katha Upanishad]]'' 2:20, states that the Big Bang theory reminds humanity that everything came from the [[Brahman]] which is "subtler than the atom, greater than the greatest."<ref name="SanatanDharma3"> {{cite book |author=Sunil Sehgal |date=1999|title=Encyclopædia of Hinduism: T–Z, Volume 5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-3OhTtBUBdgC&pg=PA297&dq=hindu+big+bang#v=onepage&q=hindu%20big%20bang&f=false|publisher=Sarup & Sons |quote=The theory is known as the 'Big Bang theory' and it reminds us of the Hindu idea that everything came from the Brahman which is "subtler than the atom, greater than the greatest" (Kathopanishad-2-20). |isbn=8176250643}}</ref> It consists of several "Big Bangs" and "Big Crunches" following each other in a cyclical manner.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Understanding Einstein|author=Moring, G.|date=1999|publisher=DK Publishing|isbn=9780786542659|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=JC4Km4_GUqUC&pg=PA341#v=onepage|page=341|accessdate=2015-08-20}}</ref><ref name="huffingtonpost">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/gadadhara-pandit-dasa/hinduism-science-spirituality-intersect_b_967628.html?ir=India|title=Hinduism: Where Science and Spirituality Intersect | Gadadhara Pandit Dasa|publisher=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=2015-08-20|date=2011-09-20}}</ref><ref name="huffingtonpost2">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/philip-goldberg/are-eastern-religions-mor_b_628533.html?ir=India|title=Are Eastern Religions More Science-Friendly? | Philip Goldberg|publisher=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=2015-08-20|date=2010-07-05}}</ref>
The ''[[Nasadiya Sukta]]'', the ''[[Hymn of Creation]]'' in the ''[[Rigveda]]'' (10:129) mentions the world beginning from a point or [[bindu (symbol)|bindu]], through the power of heat.<ref>{{Cite book| title=World scriptures: an introduction to comparative religions| first=Kramer| last=Kenneth| isbn=978-0-8091-2781-8|date=1986|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RzUAu-43W5oC&pg=PA34 |page=34| postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Human Being in Depth: A Scientific Approach to Religion|author=Swami Ranganathananda |authorlink=Ranganathananda |publisher=SUNY Press|date=1991|isbn=0-7914-0679-2 |page=21 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P0vfFZh9BIIC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=Big+Bang+theory+and+Indian+philosophy#v=onepage&q=Big%20Bang%20theory%20and%20Indian%20philosophy&f=false }}</ref> This can be seen as corresponding to the Big Bang theory.
Several prominent modern scientists have remarked that Hinduism (as also Buddhism and Jainism by extension as they share most of these philosophies) is the only religion (or civilization) in all of recorded history, that has timescales and theories in astronomy (cosmology), that appear to correspond to those of modern scientific cosmology, e.g. [[Carl Sagan]],<ref name="goodreads">{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/quotes/601581-the-hindu-religion-is-the-only-one-of-the-world-s|title=Quote by Carl Sagan: "The Hindu religion is the only one of the world..."|publisher=goodreads.com|accessdate=2015-08-20}}</ref> [[Niels Bohr]], [[Erwin Schrödinger]], [[Werner Heisenberg]],<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=Claiming Knowledge: Strategies of Epistemology from Theosophy to the New Age|author=Hammer, O.|date=2003|publisher=Brill|isbn=9789004136380|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=EZYsPQgBNioC&pg=PA283#v=onepage|page=283|accessdate=2015-08-20}}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=bAwAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60#v=onepage|page=60|accessdate=2015-08-20}}</ref><ref name="google4">{{cite book|title=Spooky Physics|author=Diem-Lane, A.|publisher=MSAC Philosophy Group|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=jPWlgmlCmMQC&pg=PA42v=onepage|page=42|accessdate=2015-08-20}}</ref> [[Robert Oppenheimer]],<ref name="google5">{{cite book|title=Oppenheimer: The Tragic Intellect|author=Thorpe, C.|date=2008|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=9780226798486|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=BWek8zJ-U7IC&pg=PA54#v=onepage|page=54|accessdate=2015-08-20}}</ref> [[E. C. George Sudarshan|George Sudarshan]],<ref name="thehindu">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/all-i-know-is-how-to-do-physics/article4340225.ece|title=‘All I know is how to do physics’ - The Hindu|publisher=thehindu.com|accessdate=2015-08-20|location=Chennai, India|first=Anand|last=Narayanan|date=2013-01-24}}</ref> [[Fritjof Capra]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fritjofcapra.net/shiva.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216202819/http://www.fritjofcapra.net/shiva.html |archivedate=2013-12-16 |df= }}</ref> etc.
'''Steady State'''
Some say there must be more than we can fathom, rather favouring the thought that chance alone cannot explain a world that's so complex and fraught. They say the Big Bang is a fact, that laws and constants have been so since one exclusive point and moment only fourteen billion years ago.
The smallest chance becomes a certainty in endless time. A boundless trace endures and shifts, unseen beyond the red horizon of our little space where supernovae — little bangs of energy and sub-atomics — flow into primordial entropy, and then re-form the latest matter that we know.
==Christianity== {{Further information|Science and the Catholic Church}}
At the November 22, 1951, opening meeting of the [[Pontifical Academy of Sciences]], [[Pope Pius XII]] declared that the Big Bang theory does not conflict with the [[Catholicism|Catholic]] concept of creation.<ref> {{cite book |last=Ferris|first=T. |date=1988 |title=Coming of age in the Milky Way |url=https://books.google.com/?id=a8nuAAAAMAAJ |publisher=[[William Morrow and Company|Morrow]] |pages=274, 438 |isbn=978-0-688-05889-0 |ref=harv }}, citing {{cite book |last=Berger |first=A. |date=1984 |title=The Big bang and Georges Lemaître: proceedings of a symposium in honour of G. Lemaître fifty years after his initiation of big-bang cosmology, Louvainla-Neuve, Belgium, 10–13 October 1983 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=eYHvAAAAMAAJ |page=387 |publisher=[[D. Reidel]] |isbn=978-90-277-1848-8 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xii/speeches/1951/documents/hf_p-xii_spe_19511122_di-serena_it.html |title=Ai soci della Pontificia Accademia delle Scienze, 22 novembre 1951 – Pio XII, Discorsi |language=Italian |date=1951-11-02 |accessdate=2012-02-23 |author=Pope Pius XII |author-link=Pope Pius XII |publisher=Tipografia Poliglotta Vaticana }}</ref> Some [[Evangelicalism|Conservative Protestant]] [[Christian denominations]] have also welcomed the Big Bang theory as supporting a historical interpretation of the doctrine of [[Creationism|creation]];<ref name="Russell - Protestant"> {{cite book |last=Russell |first=R.J. |date=2008 |title=Cosmology: From Alpha to Omega |url=https://books.google.com/?id=IvlKa6frm2EC&pg=PA40&dq=rejected+God+Fred+Hoyle+big+bang#v=onepage&q=rejected%20God%20Fred%20Hoyle%20big%20bang&f=false |publisher=[[Fortress Press]] |quote=Conservative Protestant circles have also welcomed Big Bang cosmology as supporting a historical interpretation of the doctrine of creation. |isbn=978-0-8006-6273-8 }}</ref> however, adherents of [[Young Earth creationism]], who advocate a very literal interpretation of the [[Book of Genesis]], reject the theory.
==Bahá’í Faith== {{Further information| Bahá'í Faith and science}} Bahá’u’lláh, the founder of the [[Bahá’í Faith]], has taught that the universe has "neither beginning nor ending".<ref>{{Cite book |author = Esslemont, J.E. |authorlink = John Esslemont |date = 1980 |title = Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era |edition = 5th |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-160-4 |url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/je/BNE }}</ref> In the ''[[Tablets of Bahá’u’lláh Revealed After the Kitáb-i-Aqdas|Tablet of Wisdom]]'' (''"Lawh-i-Hikmat"'', written 1873–1874). Bahá'u'lláh states: “That which hath been in existence had existed before, but not in the form thou seest today. The world of existence came into being through the heat generated from the interaction between the active force and that which is its recipient. These two are the same, yet they are different.” The terminology used here refers to [[ancient Greek]] and [[Islamic philosophy]] ([[al-Kindi]], [[Avicenna]], [[Fakhr al-Din al-Razi]] and [[Shaykh Ahmad]]).<ref name = "rafati">Rafati, Vahid. ''[http://bahai-library.com/rafati_hikmat_agents_patients Lawh-i-Hikmat: The Two Agents and the Two Patients]''. `Andalib, vol. 5, no. 19, pp. 29-38.</ref><ref>{{cite book |last = Taherzadeh |first = A. |author-link = Adib Taherzadeh |date = 1987 |title = The Revelation of Bahá'u'lláh, Volume 4: Mazra'ih & Bahji 1877-92 |publisher = George Ronald |place = Oxford, UK |isbn = 0-85398-270-8 | pages = 42 | url = http://www.peyman.info/cl/Baha'i/Others/ROB/V4/Cover.html}}</ref> In an early text, Bahá’u’lláh describes the successive creation of the four natures heat and cold (the active force), dryness and moisture (the recipients), and the [[Classical element|four elements]] fire, air, water and earth.<ref name = "rafati" /> About the phrase "That which hath been in existence had existed before, but not in the form thou seest today," [['Abdu'l-Bahá]] has stated that it means that the universe is evolving.<ref name = "rafati" /> He also states that "the substance and primary matter of contingent beings is the ethereal power, which is invisible and only known through its effects... Ethereal matter is itself both the active force and the recipient... it is the sign of the Primal Will in the phenomenal world... The ethereal matter is, therefore, the cause, since light, heat, and electricity appear from it. It is also the effect, for as vibrations take place in it, they become visible...".<ref name = "rafati" />
Jean-Marc Lepain, Robin Mihrshahi, Dale E. Lehman and Julio Savi suggest a possible relation of this statement with the Big Bang theory.<ref>Lepain, Jean-Marc (2015) [2002]. ''[http://bahai-library.com/lepain_terry_archeology_god The Archeology of the Kingdom of God]''.</ref><ref name="mihrshahi">{{cite journal | last = Mihrshahi | first = Robin | date = 2002| title = Ether, Quantum Physics and the Bahá'í Writings | journal = Australian Bahá'í Studies Journal | volume = 4 | pages = 3–20 | url = http://bahai-library.com/mihrshahi_ether_quantum_physics}}</ref><ref>Lehman, Dale E. (2005). ''[http://www.planetbahai.org/cgi-bin/articles.pl?article=222&print=Y Cosmology and the Bahá'í Writings] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128221137/http://www.planetbahai.org/cgi-bin/articles.pl?article=222&print=Y |date=2014-11-28 }}''.</ref><ref>{{Cite book | title = The Eternal Quest for God: An Introduction to the Divine Philosophy of `Abdu'l-Bahá | first = Savi | last = Julio | publisher = George Ronald | location = Oxford, UK | isbn = 0-85398-295-3 | date = 1989 | pages = 134 | url = http://bahai-library.com/pdf/s/savi_eternal_quest.pdf }}</ref>
==Islam== {{Further information|Islamic attitudes towards science|Islamic views on evolution}} Writing for the [[Kyoto University|Kyoto Bulletin of Islamic Area Studies]], Haslin Hasan and Ab. Hafiz Mat Tuah wrote that modern scientific ideas on cosmology are creating new ideas on how to interpret the Quran's cosmogonical terms.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hasan |first=Haslin |last2=Mat Tuah |first2=Ab. Hafiz |date=2014 |title=Quranic Cosmogony: Impact of Contemporary Cosmology on the Interpretation of Quranic Passages Relating to the Origin of the Universe |url=http://www.asafas.kyoto-u.ac.jp/kias/pdf/kb7/11ea2_Haslin.pdf |journal=Kyoto Bulletin of Islamic Area Studies |volume= |issue= |pages=122–140 |doi= |access-date=October 28, 2016 | quote=Our study shows that modern scientific findings do indeed influence modern Muslims’ understanding of the Quran’s cosmogonical terms, concepts and narratives by modifying the older Tafsir sources, even deviating from them altogether and offering fresh ideas. }}</ref> In particular, some modern-day Muslim groups have advocated for interpreting the term ''al-sama'', traditionally believed to be a reference to both the sky and the [[seven heavens]],<ref>{{cite book|title=The Qur'an: An Encyclopedia|editor=Oliver Leaman|page=258|year=2005|publisher=Routledge}}</ref> as instead referring to the universe as a whole.
[[Mirza Tahir Ahmad]], head of the [[Ahmadiyya]] Muslim community, asserted in his book [[Revelation, Rationality, Knowledge & Truth]] that the Big Bang theory was foretold in the [[Quran]]. He referenced the verse 30 of the [[Al-Anbiya|Sūrat al-Anbiyāʼ]], which ostensibly mentions the [[initial singularity]]:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ahmad|first1=Mirza Tahir|title=The Quran and Cosmology|url=https://www.alislam.org/library/books/revelation/part_4_section_5.html|website=Al Islam|accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.school-for-champions.com/religion/big_bang_theory_and_religion.htm#.WG71SvDhDIU|title=Big Bang Theory and Religion by Ron Kurtus - Succeed in Understanding Religion: School for Champions|website=www.school-for-champions.com|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref>
{{quote | Have those who disbelieved not considered that the heavens and the earth were a joined entity, and We separated them and made from water every living thing? Then will they not believe? | {{cite quran|21|30|style=ref}} }}
This view that the Qu'ran references the initial singularity of the Big Bang is also accepted by many Muslim scholars outside of the Ahmadiyya community such as [[Muhammad Tahir-ul-Qadri]], who is a [[Sufi]] scholar, and [[Muhammad Asad]], who was a nondenominational Muslim scholar.<ref name=ResearchFoundation/><ref name = "Asad">{{Cite book |url=http://muhammad-asad.com/Message-of-Quran.pdf |last = Asad |first = Muhammad |authorlink = Muhammad Asad |date = 1984 |title = The Message of the Qu'rán |publisher = Dar al-Andalus Limited |location = Gibraltar, Spain |isbn = 1904510000 |page=676}}</ref> Further, some scholars such as Faheem Ashraf of the Islamic Research Foundation International, Inc. and Sheikh [[Omar Suleiman (Imam)|Omar Suleiman]] of the Yaqeen Institute for Islamic Research argue that the scientific theory of an [[Metric expansion of space|expanding universe]] is described in [[adh-Dhariyat|Sūrat adh-Dhāriyāt]]:<ref name=ResearchFoundation>{{cite web|url=http://www.irfi.org/articles2/articles_3951_4000/islamic%20concept%20of%20creation%20of%20universehtml.htm|title=Islamic Concept of Creation of Universe Big Bang and Science-Religion Interaction|first=Faheem|last=Ashraf|access-date=3 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://islam-science.net/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/EVOLUTION-AND-ISLAM’S-QUANTUM-QUESTION.pdf|title=Islam's Quantum Question: Reconciling Muslim Tradition and Modern Science|first=Nidhal|last=Guessoum|publisher=I.B.Tauris|date=Oct 30, 2010|access-date=3 March 2017|isbn=9780857730756|page=351}}</ref>
{{quote | And the heaven We constructed with strength, and indeed, We are [its] expander. | {{cite quran|51|47|style=ref}} }}

Oxford University Press (1995), {{ISBN|0-19-510275-4}}. * Pius XII (1952), "Modern Science and the Existence of God," ''The Catholic Mind'' 49:182–192. * Ahmad, Mirza Tahir, ''Revelation, Rationality, Knowledge & Truth'' Islam International Publications Ltd (1987), {{ISBN|1-85372-640-0}}. [http://www.alislam.org/library/books/revelation/part_4_section_5.html The Quran and Cosmology] * Wickman, Leslie, "God of the Big Bang: How Modern Science Affirms the Creator," Worthy Publishing (2015), {{ISBN|978-1617954252}}.

It discusses the connection between the Big Bang and God from a Christian perspective. * [http://www.school-for-champions.com/religion/big_bang_theory_and_religion.htm Big Bang Theory and Religion, by Ron Kurtis, Physicist] * [http://www.asa3.org/ASA/PSCF/1995/PSCF9-95Philippidis.html.ori Cosmic Controversy: The Big Bang and Genesis 1] published by the [[American Scientific Affiliation]], an organisation of Christians in the sciences. * {{cite web |last=Oliver |first=Simon |title=Creation and Science |url=http://www.bibledex.com/verses/genesis_beginning.html |work=Bibledex Verses |publisher=[[Brady Haran]] for the [[University of Nottingham]]}}

{{Use Indian English|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox judge | honorific-prefix =[[The Honourable]] | name = Sheikh Anwarul Haq
شیخ انوار الحق | honorific-suffix = | image =Justice_Anwar_Ul_Haq.jpg | image_size =290px | alt = | caption =Chief Justice Sheikh Anwarul Haq (1917–1995) | office =[[Chief Justice of Pakistan]] | term_start =23 September 1977 | term_end =25 March 1981 | nominator =[[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] | appointer =[[Fazal Ilahi Chaudhry]] | predecessor =[[Muhammad Yaqub Ali|Yaqub Ali]] | successor = [[Mohammad Haleem]] | office2 =[[Acting President of Pakistan]] | term_start2 =20 April 1978 | term_end2 =7 May 1978 | predecessor2 =[[Fazlul Qadir Chaudhry]]
{{small|(29 November 1963 – 12 June 1965)}} | successor2 =[[Wasim Sajjad]]
{{small|(18 July 1993 – 14 November 1993)}} | office3 =[[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|Senior Justice]] of the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]] | term_start3 =16 October 1972 | term_end3 =23 September 1977 | nominator3 =Zulfikar Ali Bhutto | appointer3 = | predecessor3 = | successor3 = | pronunciation = | birth_name =Sheikh Anwarul Haq | birth_date ={{birth date|1917|5|11|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Jullundur]], [[British Raj|British Indian Empire]]
(now [[India]]) | death_date ={{death date and age|1995|3|3|1917|5|11|df=y}} | death_place =[[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship ={{flag icon|British Raj}} [[British subject]] {{small|(1917–1947)}}
{{PAK}} {{small|(1947–1995)}} | nationality = | party = | otherparty = | height = | spouse = | partner = | relations = | children = | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | residence = | education = | alma_mater =[[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]] | occupation = | profession =Jurist | known_for = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | awards = | blank1 = | data1 = | blank2 = | data2 = | blank3 = | data3 = | blank4 = | data4 = | blank5 = | data5 = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | nickname = | allegiance = | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | unit = | commands = | battles = | mawards = | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | footnotes = }} [[Chief Justice]] '''Sheikh Anwarul Haq''' ({{lang-ur|شیخ انوار الحق}}‎ ; 11 May 1917 – 3 March 1995), was a [[Pakistan]]i [[jurist]] and an academic who served as the [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] of [[Pakistan]] from 23 September 1977 until resigning on 25 March 1981. Educated as an [[Economics|economist]] at the DAV College and the [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]] in [[Lahore]], he served as a [[Bureaucrat|civil servant]] of the [[Indian Civil Service (British India)|Indian Civil Service]] as an appointee to lead the [[Municipal governance in India|municipal governance]] in the [[British Indian Empire|British India]] in 1944. He continued serving in the [[Civil Service of Pakistan|civil service]] after the [[Indian Independence Act 1947|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] as a result of [[Partition of India|partition]] of British India in 1947 and subsequently elevated as a judge in the [[Sindh High Court]] in 1957. In 1962, he was nominated to be served in the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] and later appointed as [[Chief Justice of Lahore High Court|Chief Justice]] of [[Lahore High Court]] in 1970 before his reappointment as a [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|Senior Justice]] of the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]] in 1971. He 1972, he earned public and international notability when he co-chaired the [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission|War Enquiry Commission]] with Chief Justice [[Hamoodur Rahman]] to investigate the [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|economic and military collapse]] of Pakistan in a [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|war against]] India in 1971 that led to the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|succession]] of [[East Pakistan]] as [[Bangladesh]]. He was known for his judicial [[Conservatism in Pakistan|conservative]] philosophical leanings and is noted in [[Political history of Pakistan|country's political history]] for providing [[Doctrine of necessity|legality]] for the [[1977 Pakistani coup d'état|martial law]] upheld by [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|chief of army staff]] General [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]] to restore [[Law and order (politics)|law and order]], in the light of [[doctrine of necessity]], as part of his conservative leanings.{{cite book|last1=Burki|first1=Shahid Javed|title=Historical Dictionary of Pakistan|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9781442241480|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rk-sBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&dq=Sheikh+Anwarul+Haq&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwig0MLd1u3OAhVLph4KHeF2BbkQuwUIITAA#v=onepage&q=Sheikh%20Anwarul%20Haq&f=false|accessdate=1 September 2016|language=en}} In addition, he also heard the case of [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] and controversially upheld the [[Capital punishment|capital sentence]] by the [[Lahore High Court]] for [[Political murder|authorizing]] the murder of a political opponent.{{cite book|last1=Constable|first1=Pamela|title=Playing with Fire: Pakistan at War with Itself|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|isbn=9780679603450|page=219|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-wU1aVyM9IC&pg=PA219&dq=Sheikh+Anwarul+Haq+bhutto&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3j_mr4u3OAhXEXB4KHXbhA4sQuwUIJjAB#v=onepage&q=Sheikh%20Anwarul%20Haq%20bhutto&f=false|accessdate=1 September 2016|language=en}} In 1981, Haq notably refused to take an oath under the [[Provisional Constitutional Order|imposed PCO]], resigning on [[Conscientiousness|conscientious grounds]].{{cite web|title=Chief Justice Anwar ul Haq|url=http://www.kppsc.com.pk/pages/?Anwarul-haq-chief-justice-sheikh-1925-1995|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911072934/http://www.kppsc.com.pk/pages/?Anwarul-haq-chief-justice-sheikh-1925-1995|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 September 2016|website=www.kppsc.com.pk|accessdate=1 September 2016}} ==Biography== ===Early life and public service=== Sheikh Anwarul Haq was born in [[Jalandhar|Jullunder]], [[British Punjab|Punjab]], [[British India]] on 11 May 1917, to a [[Punjabi people|Punjabi family]].{{cite book|title=The All Pakistan Legal Decisions|date=1977|publisher=All-Pakistan Legal Decisions|pages=259–260|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xjA-AQAAIAAJ&q=justice+anwar+ul+haq+born+1917&dq=justice+anwar+ul+haq+born+1917&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijv7Wl5u3OAhVBJB4KHYHODvIQ6AEIHDAA|accessdate=1 September 2016|language=en}} S. Anwarul Haq earned early education from Jullunder and [[Wazirabad]], passing his [[matriculation]] from Jullunder in 1932.{{rp|259}} He stood first in matriculation that earned him a [[scholarship]] to attend the DAV College in 1932{{Citation needed|reason=|date=June 2018}}. In 1936, he earned [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[Economics]] and [[Political science]] and went on to attend the [[D.A.V. College, Lahore]] of [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]], where he earned an [[master's degree|MA]] in [[Economics]] in 1938.{{cite book|title=The All Pakistan Legal Decisions|date=1972|publisher=The All-Pakistan Legal Decisions|pages=53–54|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sys-AQAAIAAJ&dq=justice+anwar+ul+haq+dav+college&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+dav+college|accessdate=1 September 2016|language=en}} He ranked first in [[Master of Arts|MA]] in Economics examination at the [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]], setting a new record in that subject.{{rp|54}} During his time at the [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]], Haq participated in a large number of [[wikt:declamation|declamation]] contests and prize debates and was often judged as the best speaker.{{rp|55}} From 1936–38, he was an activist of [[All-India Muslim League]] and was a student advocate of the assertion of the [[Muslim nationalism in South Asia|separate identity]] of [[Indian Muslims|Indian Muslim]]s.{{rp|53–54}} He attended the [[All-India Muslim League]] meeting in [[Calcutta]] in December 1937 as a student delegate.{{rp|54}} In 1939, he was selected and joined the [[Indian Civil Service (British India)|Indian Civil Service]] and went to [[United Kingdom]] to be educated in [[Oxford]].{{rp|53–54}} Upon returning in 1940, he was appointed Assistant Commissioner at [[Ferozepur]] and later appointed as [[Undersecretary]] of [[Punjab, British India|Punjab]] and the [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–55)|North-West Frontier]] from 1942 until 1944.{{rp|214}}{{cite book|last1=British Government|first1=His Majesty's Stationery Office, 1944|title=India Office and Burma Office List Advertiser|date=1945|publisher=Harrison & Sons Ltd.|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XiUbAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=Sheikh+Anwarul+Haq+1944&source=bl&ots=OYOZ44SMHB&sig=7pfF7HoHTUyMBWEGGrum2fHnLMM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwii3bzgj9zQAhWov1QKHQseD4oQ6AEISTAL#v=onepage&q=Sheikh%20Anwarul%20Haq%201944&f=false|accessdate=5 December 2016|language=en|format=googlebook}} In 1944, he was appointed as Sub Divisional Magistrate at the [[Dalhousie, India]] and heard various cases involving the civil lawsuits.{{cite web|title=Sheikh Anwarul Haque vs The State Of Bihar & Ors on 31 August, 2015|url=https://indiankanoon.org/doc/196202775/|website=indiankanoon.org|publisher=The Land Acquisition Act, 1894|accessdate=5 December 2016}} During the same time, he was sent to [[Gurdaspur]] and was appointed as Deputy Commissioner and later elevated as Session Judge as well as Assistant Commissioner in 1946.{{cite web|title=Lahore High Court, Lahore|url=http://sys.lhc.gov.pk/?page_id=58|website=sys.lhc.gov.pk|publisher=Lahore High Court, Lahore Press|accessdate=5 December 2016}} For a short brief of time, he served as the deputy commissioner of [[Hisar (city)|Hissar]] (in [[East Punjab]]) in 1946, before joining the [[1946 Cabinet Mission to India|Cabinet Mission]] to be served as its Secretary to the [[Partition of Punjab|Partition Steering Committee for the Punjab]] in 1947. After the [[Independence of Pakistan|establishment]] of [[Pakistan]] as a result of [[Partition of India|partition]] of [[British Indian Empire|British India]] by the [[British Empire]], he [[Pakistani citizenship|opted]] for Pakistan and appointed as deputy commissioner of [[Rawalpindi]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], Pakistan.{{rp|696}}{{cite book|last1=Zaidi|first1=Z. H.|last2=Project|first2=Quaid-i-Azam Papers|title=Quaid-i-Azam Mohammad Ali Jinnah Papers: Pakistan : pangs of birth, 15 August-30 September 1947|publisher=Quaid-i-Azam Papers Project, National Archives of Pakistan|isbn=9789698156091|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OgRuAAAAMAAJ&q=Sheikh+Anwar+Ul+Haq+Deputy+Commissioner&dq=Sheikh+Anwar+Ul+Haq+Deputy+Commissioner&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik9K6Z7PnQAhWIwFQKHYWjD5MQ6wEIJjAD|accessdate=16 December 2016|language=en}} During this time, he worked towards managing the [[Indians in Pakistan|Indian emigrants]] settling in Pakistan.{{rp|228}}{{cite book|last1=GoP|first1=Government of Pakistan|title=The Journey to Pakistan: A Documentation on Refugees of 1947|publisher=Government of Pakistan, Cabinet Secretariat, Cabinet Division, National Documentation Centre|accessdate=16 December 2016|language=en}} From 1948–52, he served in the [[Pakistan Administrative Service|bureaucracy]] as deputy commissioner of [[Montgomery (Pakistan)|Montgomery]] and [[Sialkot]]. In 1952, he joined the [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|Ministry of Defence]] (MoD) as its deputy secretary until 1954 when he left for the [[United Kingdom]] to attend the [[Imperial Defence College]] in [[London]].{{cite web|last1=Baqa|first1=Khurram|title=OPF|url=http://www.opf.org.pk/web/almanac/J/judicary.htm|website=www.opf.org.pk|publisher=OPF Khurram|accessdate=16 December 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220154259/http://www.opf.org.pk/web/almanac/J/judicary.htm|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=dmy-all}} In 1956, he earned the [[Degree (academic)|degree]] and secured his graduation from the Imperial Defence College and subsequently returned to Pakistan. He was appointed as joint secretary in MoD but later moved to [[Ministry of Law and Justice (Pakistan)|Ministry of Law and Justice]] (MoLJ) to pursue career as federal judge. ===Supreme court and chief justice=== In 1957, he was elevated as [[District Courts of Pakistan|district-session judge]] in [[Sindh High Court]] but later moved to [[Lahore High Court]] in Punjab in 1958.{{rp|225–247}}{{cite book|last1=Yousaf|first1=Nasim|title=Pakistan's Birth & Allama Mashraqi: Chronology & Statements, Period,1947–1963|publisher=AMZ Publications|isbn=9780976033349|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PofFyAw9pgEC&pg=PA225&dq=Sheikh+Anwar+Ul+Haq+District+and+Sessions&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi13vrJ7_nQAhWLjVQKHSdaC04Q6wEIGzAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=16 December 2016|language=en}} In 1959, he was appointed as a judge in the [[West Pakistan High Court]] and moved on to the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] as a [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|senior justice]] in 1962. In 1965, he was appointed as the deputy leader of the Pakistan Delegation to the Third Commonwealth and Empire Law Conference held at [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] in 1965. In 1967, he was appointed as a member of the Law Reform Commission led by [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] [[Alvin Robert Cornelius]] that conducted the various case studies on land reforms in Pakistan.{{rp|266–267}}{{cite book|last1=Mian|first1=Ajmal|title=A Judge Speaks Out|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195799842|language=en}} In 1969, he was selected to lead a Legal Expert Delegation to [[Somalia]] to provide expertise in overviewing the [[1969 in Somalia|constitutional crises]] in Somalia. In 1970, he was elevated as [[Chief Justice of Lahore High Court|Chief Justice]] of the [[Lahore High Court]] by President [[Yahya Khan]] who issued the decree, the [[Legal Framework Order, 1970|LFO No. 1970]] that dissolved the status of [[West Pakistan]].{{rp|184–186}}{{cite book|last1=Burki|first1=Shahid Javed|last2=Baxter|first2=Craig|last3=LaPorte|first3=Robert|last4=Azfar|first4=Kamal|title=Pakistan Under the Military: Eleven Years of Zia Ul-Haq|date=1991|publisher=Westview Press|isbn=9780813379852|language=en}} He witnessed the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971|war]] between [[India]] and [[Pakistan]] that resulted in the [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|succession]] of East Pakistan as [[Bangladesh]].{{rp|41–42}}{{cite book|last1=Matīna|first1=Ābadula|title=Bangladesh liberation struggle, 1971: the role of USA, China, Soviet Union & India|date=1991|publisher=Radical Asia Publications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JIG6AAAAIAAJ&dq=Justice+anwar+ul+haq+1971+Bangladesh&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Justice+anwar+ul+haq+|accessdate=17 December 2016|language=en}} On 26 December 1971, he was named as a member of the [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission|War Enquiry Commission]] (WEC) alongside with Chief Justice [[Hamoodur Rahman]], and the chief justices of the [[Sindh High Court|Sindh]], [[Balochistan High Court|Balochistan]], and [[Lahore High Court|Punjab High Court]], formed by the Chief Justice Rahman on the request of then-[[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]].{{rp|229–230}}{{cite book|last1=Dixit|first1=J. N.|title=India-Pakistan in War and Peace|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134407583|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mdWCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA230&dq=justice+s+anwar+ul+haq&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif6vintPrQAhUnjVQKHSStAmwQ6wEIKTAD#v=onepage&q&f=false|language=en}} On 1 January 1972, he was re-elevated as the [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|senior justice]] at the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]].{{rp|141}}{{cite book|last1=Court|first1=Pakistan Supreme|title=Annual Report|publisher=Secretariat, Law and Justice Commission of Pakistan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5kg-AQAAIAAJ&dq=sheikh+anwar+ul+haq+appointed+1971+justice+supreme+court&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sheikh+anwar+ul+haq+a|accessdate=17 December 2016|language=en}} {{Clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" ! span=col style="width:7%;" | Temporal Order ! span=col style="width:57%;" | Name of Post ! span=col style="width:18%;" | From ! span=col style="width:18%;" | To |- |1||Secretary to the [[Punjab region|Punjab]] and [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|North-West Frontier Province]] Public Service Commission. Secretary to [[Government of Punjab, Pakistan]], Medical & Local Government Department||22 February 1944||29 February 1944 |- |2||Under-Secretary to Government of Punjab, Pakistan Revenue Department, He was interested in academic and educational activities and had been a member of the Syndicates of: * [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]] * [[University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore]] * [[Agricultural University of Lyallpur]] (now [[Faisalabad]]) * [[Allama Iqbal Open University]], [[Islamabad]] Haq was President of the [[Anjuman-e-Himayat-e-Islam|Himayat-i-Islam Law College, Lahore]], and member of the [[University Law College, Lahore]] committee{{Which|date=November 2012|reason=Which committee?}} for several years. He was acting Vice-Chancellor of [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]] on multiple occasions. He was appointed as a member of the 1971 War Inquiry Commission from January 1972 to November 1974 along with CJ [[Hamoodur Rahman]]. He was also appointed as Chairman of the National Pay Commission and Armed Forces Pay Commission in January 1976. He represented the Pakistan Supreme Court at the centenary celebrations of the [[Supreme Court of Ghana]] at [[Accra]] in October 1976. He was appointed Chairman of the Commission on the [[Indus River]] System in September 1977. He was appointed Chairman of the Civil Services Commission in February 1978.
